like the title say i m doing bad at work i work a a claim adjuster for a big insurance company and i m really bad at it the job requires a tremendous amount of organization and i just simply do not have those skill it s my first big job out of college and i m failing it embarrassing and it s crushing my confidence i constantly worry about my job security being this anxious all the time is making me run out of steam quickly i find it hard to even force myself to look for another job bc of the little free time i get and how tired i am at the end of the day i feel like a burden to my parent and girlfriend because i constantly vent break down to them i did start seeing a therapist recently and he s helped but it feel like it build up a lot until i get to talk it out with him what trigged me to write this today is i made another fuck up at work and had to tell my bos she s extremely nice but had to be honest with me that my performance could result in corrective action i know that doesn t mean termination exactly but that is definitely on the table i have so many case and i just know there s at least a couple more fuck ups in there that i haven t found yet i feel like it s inevitable that i get let go and i m just not prepared to deal with the embarrassment of it it s eating at me

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're going through a really tough time at work and it's affecting your confidence, job security, and overall well-being. It's great that you've started seeing a therapist to help you cope with these feelings, but it's understandable that you feel like it builds up until you can talk it out with him.

Firstly, I want to acknowledge the bravery it took for you to reach out and share your struggles. It takes courage to recognize when we need support and to take steps towards seeking help. Your therapist is there to provide guidance and help you navigate through difficult emotions, so it's good that you have someone to lean on during this challenging period.

Regarding your job performance, it's important to remember that everyone makes mistakes, especially when they're new to a role or under a lot of pressure. It's natural to feel overwhelmed by the tremendous amount of organization required as a claim adjuster, especially if it doesn't align with your skillset. However, it's important not to be too hard on yourself and to focus on finding strategies that can improve your performance.

One suggestion I have is to create a system or use organizational tools to help you manage your cases more effectively. This could include using a digital calendar or task manager to keep track of deadlines, setting reminders for yourself, and color-coding tasks based on priority. By implementing a structured approach, you may find it easier to stay organized and reduce the likelihood of making errors.

Additionally, consider reaching out to colleagues or supervisors who might be able to offer guidance or support. They may have valuable insights or tips based on their own experiences. Exploring additional training opportunities or asking for mentorship could also be beneficial in enhancing your skills and improving your job performance.

In terms of managing anxiety and the overwhelming burden you're feeling, it's crucial to prioritize self-care. Make sure you're taking breaks throughout the day, even if they're short ones, to give yourself time to recharge. Engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation outside of work can help replenish your energy and reduce stress.

If possible, try to set aside some dedicated time each day to search for other job opportunities. Even if it feels exhausting and you're worried about failing again, exploring different options can provide a sense of empowerment and control over your situation. Consider updating your resume, networking with professionals in your field, and reaching out to career counseling services for support.

Lastly, remember that you are not a burden to your parents or girlfriend. It's completely normal to vent and lean on loved ones during difficult times. Sharing your feelings with them is a way for them to understand what you're going through and offer their support. They care about you and want to help, so don't hesitate to reach out when you need them.

Stay committed to therapy, keep exploring strategies to improve your job performance, prioritize self-care, and actively search for other job opportunities. Remember that progress takes time, and it's okay to make mistakes along the way. You have already shown resilience by seeking therapy and reaching out for guidance. Keep believing in yourself and trust that you can find ways to overcome these challenges.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i need some help badly i suffer too much my depression ha gone from a depression i wa able to function on i wa a everyday gym user ate well slept well grade were alright now my depression is horrific i tried the gym the other day and saw myself in the mirror and wanted to pick up a weight and smash my head in i don t eat i don t sleep i ve lost weight badly my hair is always ridiculed someone always go out of there way to speak to me or about me leave me alone i would bet money if you ask my couple of friend and my family doe he have depression they would say no way he s happy i m dying inside suicidal thought used to be a comforting thing for me whenever something bad happened i said i won t be here so it won t matter now it s getting to the point where it seems like my only solution i m such a gentle great soul why doe my brain treat me like a piece of dirt why doe my brain force me to thrive to look perfect i ve resorted to self harm i ve done it twice a month or two ago and it felt great i cut up my thigh badly i ve tried to not make that a habit tho i m just a year old kid how tf am i giving up already on life my beautiful parent and family and pet and i choose to be a disgusting loser i wish i didn t have such a amazing family so i didn t feel guilty i know this is long and i know people won t read this on a stupid reddit page but i had to vent my main reason for depression are body dysmorphia worst part and most crippling lack of social life fear of driving while everyone else doe lack of aspiration don t know what i m doing for college don t have a career choice lack of attention from opposite sex least painful one but it definitely hurt badly i ve never told a single person about depression can someone save my life

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're going through a really tough time right now, and I'm here to offer some guidance and support. Dealing with depression can be incredibly challenging, but there are steps you can take to help improve your situation.

Firstly, it's important to acknowledge the impact that body dysmorphia and lack of social life are having on your mental health. These issues can contribute to feelings of low self-worth and isolation. It might be helpful to explore these specific areas in more depth to better understand how they are affecting you. Consider seeking out resources or support groups that specialize in body dysmorphia and social anxiety. Connecting with others who have similar experiences may provide you with a sense of validation and understanding.

Regarding your lack of aspiration and not knowing what to do for college or career choice, it can be overwhelming when faced with decisions about your future. Take some time to reflect on your interests, strengths, and values. Exploring different fields of study or potential career paths could give you a clearer direction. Additionally, consider reaching out to guidance counselors or career coaches for assistance in navigating this process.

The loss of attention from the opposite sex may also be contributing to your insecurities. Remember that societal standards of beauty and attraction can be distorted and unrealistic. Focus on building a healthy sense of self-worth based on your own unique qualities, rather than relying solely on external validation. Surrounding yourself with supportive friends and family members who appreciate you for who you are can help counteract negative thoughts and beliefs.

Self-harm is a serious concern, and it's important to reach out for professional help if you haven't already done so. Therapists and counselors can provide you with healthier coping mechanisms and strategies to manage your emotions. They can also explore any underlying factors contributing to your self-harming behaviors. Remember, there is no shame in asking for help.

While venting online can provide temporary relief, it's essential to establish a support system in real life. Consider confiding in a trusted friend or family member about what you're going through. Opening up to someone who cares about you can offer emotional support and potentially lead to helpful conversations.

Lastly, please remember that you are not a disgusting loser. Depression can make us feel helpless and worthless, but those thoughts are not reflective of reality. You deserve love, happiness, and fulfillment just like anyone else. It's important to challenge negative thoughts and remind yourself of your worth.

While I'm here to offer guidance, it's crucial to seek professional help from a mental health expert who can provide you with personalized support and treatment options. They can work with you to develop coping strategies tailored to your specific needs. Remember, you don't have to face this alone, and there is hope for improvement.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

hey r anxiety i didn t know where to put this but figured it s mainly a side effect of my anxiety so i went with here i ll just get into it i m a 9 yo male that s been diagnosed with anxiety and other disorder mdd odd adhd polysubstance addiction this may sound weird but i wanted to know if you guy recluse by choice a someone who want to have friend and a strong social aspect in life but just doesn t have the social skill to i m curious if you have a similar experience knowing that it s not a choice is probably the hardest part for me like i see everyone out having fun spending the day with their friend and it destroys me inside knowing that i don t won t ever have that i live on the sideline which make me want to stay inside even more to avoid seeing that and feeling so i sit in my room the whole day getting high the only other place i go to is my job which i can t even look up at eye level out of fear of accidently making eye contact with someone i just feel like everyone s automatically put off by me which then make me act in a way that actually doe put them off i just want someone to talk to that s not either my mom or my dad i thought about it and realized that once my parent die i will have nobody which at that point what s my life worth

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 Hey there,

I can understand how challenging it must be for you to navigate social situations and feel like you're on the sidelines. It's completely understandable that you want friends and a strong social aspect in your life, and it's not uncommon to question if your lack of social skills is the reason why you struggle with this.

Firstly, I want you to know that your anxiety and other disorders (MDD, ODD, ADHD, and polysubstance addiction) are valid and real challenges that you're facing. They can significantly impact your social skills and overall well-being. It's important to recognize that these conditions are not a choice and that you're doing your best to cope with them.

Feeling isolated and lacking genuine connections with others can indeed be incredibly painful. Seeing others having fun with their friends while you're sitting on the sidelines can bring up feelings of envy, sadness, and even resentment. Avoiding social situations may provide temporary relief from these negative emotions, but it can also reinforce the cycle of feeling disconnected.

One suggestion I have is to consider seeking professional help from a therapist or counselor who specializes in working with children and adolescents. They can provide you with a safe space to explore your feelings, develop coping strategies, and work on building your social skills. Therapy can be beneficial in many ways, such as helping you understand why you may feel uncomfortable making eye contact or how your fears and insecurities contribute to the strained relationships.

Additionally, finding supportive communities or groups where you can connect with others who have similar experiences could be helpful. These communities can offer understanding, empathy, and acceptance, which may help alleviate some of the loneliness you're experiencing. Online platforms and local support groups are great resources to consider exploring.

It's important to remember that having friends and a strong social aspect in life is valuable, but it's not everything. There are other meaningful connections and fulfilling aspects of life that you can explore and cultivate. Engaging in hobbies, interests, or even volunteering can provide opportunities to meet like-minded individuals and develop connections based on shared passions.

Lastly, regarding your thoughts about having nobody once your parents pass away, it's crucial to address these feelings of despair and worthlessness. It can be helpful to discuss these concerns with a mental health professional who can provide you with appropriate support and guidance. They can help you develop coping strategies and explore ways to build a support system that extends beyond your immediate family.

Remember, you're not alone in this journey, and there are resources available to help you navigate through these challenges. Keep in mind that building healthy relationships takes time and effort, but with the right support and strategies, you can work towards developing meaningful connections and finding a sense of belonging.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i saw a new pcp for an annual physical and while i wa there figured i d mention some of the physical symptom of anxiety i wa having to make sure it wa not actually medical i told her it often feel like my throat is really tight and on the verge of closing her only reply a she roll her eye that is literally impossible if your throat wa closing you wouldn t be talking to me right now me no duh obviously not but it feel like it s closing she wa the worst doctor i ve ever seen which is saying a lot and i wa so mad walking out of that appointment for other reason a well but the day after a my throat wa tightening i just remembered her saying it s literally impossible and couldn t stop laughing

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you had a frustrating experience with your primary care physician (PCP) during your annual physical. It's important to communicate any concerns or symptoms you have, even if they may be related to anxiety, as it's always good to rule out any medical causes.

In regards to the tightness in your throat that you mentioned, it can be a common physical symptom of anxiety. Although it may feel like your throat is closing, it's important to remember that it's not actually closing, but rather the sensation caused by anxiety. This sensation can be distressing, and it's understandable that you wanted to bring it up with your doctor.

Unfortunately, it seems like your interaction with your PCP wasn't very helpful or empathetic. Rolling her eyes and dismissing your concerns is not an appropriate response from a healthcare professional. It's unfortunate that this led to frustration and anger, and I can understand why you would question whether she is the worst doctor you've ever seen.

The fact that you couldn't stop laughing the day after your appointment when you remembered her saying it's impossible for your throat to close suggests that the experience may have had an impact on you. Laughing can sometimes be a way of coping with frustration or disbelief.

Moving forward, it might be beneficial for you to find a new PCP who is more understanding and willing to listen to your concerns without dismissing them. Building a trusting relationship with a healthcare provider who takes your symptoms seriously is crucial for your overall well-being.

If these physical symptoms of anxiety continue to bother you, it could also be helpful to explore coping strategies or techniques with a mental health professional. They can provide guidance tailored to your specific needs and help you develop effective ways to manage your anxiety symptoms.

Remember, your feelings and experiences are valid, and it's important to advocate for yourself when it comes to your health. Don't hesitate to seek out a healthcare team that values your concerns and works collaboratively with you towards better understanding and managing your symptoms.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i ve noticed that for a few glorious minute in the morning right after waking up i m great calm unbothered soft but then i can feel stress in my body and then i m not sure how to get rid of it and it build a anxiety doe how do you all get rid of body stress in the early morning

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's wonderful that you've noticed those moments of calm and clarity in the morning. It can be frustrating when stress and anxiety start to build up shortly after waking up. Here are a few suggestions to help you manage body stress in the early morning:

1. Take a moment to stretch: When you first wake up, try spending a few minutes stretching your body. This can help release any tension or stiffness that has built up overnight. Focus on deep breathing as you stretch, allowing yourself to fully relax into each movement.

2. Practice mindfulness: Mindfulness exercises can be helpful in grounding yourself and reducing anxiety. Try taking a few minutes each morning to simply observe your thoughts and sensations without judgment. You can do this by sitting quietly and paying attention to your breath or engaging in a guided mindfulness meditation.

3. Engage in gentle movement: Consider incorporating gentle exercise into your morning routine. This could include activities like yoga, tai chi, or even just going for a walk. Engaging in physical activity early in the day can help release endorphins, which are natural mood boosters.

4. Prioritize self-care: Make sure you're taking care of yourself throughout the day. This includes getting enough sleep, eating nutritious meals, and engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation. When you prioritize self-care, it can help reduce overall stress levels and contribute to a sense of well-being.

5. Seek support: If your experience with body stress and anxiety persists or becomes overwhelming, it may be beneficial to seek support from a mental health professional. They can provide personalized guidance and strategies to help you manage your specific symptoms.

Remember, everyone's experience is unique, so it may take some trial and error to find what works best for you. Be patient with yourself and celebrate the small victories along the way.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i 9 f moved to a different state to support my partner while they re at school we went from a duel income household to me being the breadwinner i wa diagnosed with adhd anxiety and depression last year and am on med and in therapy i just keep screwing up at work the work isn t hard but i m making stupid mistake i feel like im not doing anything correctly i try to be thorough and am told by my bos that i m getting too caught up in the detail i try to be quick and cover the basic and am told that it isn t my best work i have no idea what to do i m told to ask question if i don t understand by my bos and when i do she s short with me example i asked if i should include document with a proposal because the last time i did there wa push back from someone saying they didn t need to provide the document she replied if i wa asking if i needed to follow to the standard operative procedure i feel stuck my performance ha been worse partially due to depression which ha affected my focus cue adhd issue med for that aren t working great i just feel so stuck i m literally cry once a week bc i feel like i m failing so badly i m literally doing working extra because i m behind and not charging for it bc i just feel like i m so behind i started this new job and wa immediately sent home to telework full time so i can t just ask the people around me for help

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're facing a lot of challenges in your new job and dealing with the added pressure of being the breadwinner while supporting your partner through school. It's understandable that you feel stuck and frustrated with the feedback you're receiving from your boss.

Firstly, it's important to acknowledge that adjusting to a new job can be difficult, especially when you're also managing ADHD, anxiety, and depression. The fact that you're on medication and in therapy shows that you're taking steps to manage your mental health, which is commendable. However, if you feel like the meds aren't working great for your focus or the therapy isn't providing enough support, it might be worth discussing this with your healthcare provider. They may be able to adjust your medication or suggest additional coping strategies tailored to your specific needs.

In terms of your performance at work, it's clear that you're putting in effort and trying your best. Making stupid mistakes and feeling uncertain about what you're doing can be incredibly frustrating, especially when you seek feedback by asking questions and still receive short responses or criticism. It's important to remember that everyone makes mistakes, and seeking clarification is a sign of proactive learning rather than incompetence.

To handle the situation better, consider keeping a record of your interactions with your boss. Write down the questions you ask, their responses, and any follow-up actions taken. This will not only help you stay organized but also provide evidence of your initiative and willingness to seek guidance when needed. Additionally, it may be helpful to schedule regular check-ins with your boss to discuss your progress, concerns, and any specific expectations they have. This will give you both an opportunity to communicate openly and address any issues before they escalate.

Regarding the tension between focusing on details versus covering basic requirements, finding a balance is crucial. One approach could be to establish a clear workflow or checklist for completing tasks. This way, you can ensure thoroughness without getting caught up in excessive detail. Prioritize essential steps and identify which aspects are most important to your boss. By understanding their expectations, you can align your work style accordingly.

Since you mentioned struggling with teleworking full-time, it's understandable that you can't ask colleagues for help as easily as you could in person. Consider reaching out to them through email or instant messaging platforms. Even if it feels intimidating, don't hesitate to reach out to your coworkers for support or clarification. Remember, everyone was new once and might have faced similar challenges.

Lastly, while working extra to catch up may seem like a good idea, it's important to set boundaries and value your own time and energy. Continually working beyond your capacity can lead to burnout and worsen the impact of depression on your productivity. Instead, focus on prioritizing tasks, setting realistic goals, and breaking larger tasks into smaller, manageable chunks. Celebrate small wins along the way to boost your motivation.

Remember, it's normal to feel overwhelmed and frustrated in a new job, especially when dealing with mental health challenges. Be patient with yourself, seek support from your healthcare provider and coworkers, and keep refining your approach. You're doing your best, and with time and experience, you'll find what works best for you.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
gon na graduate highschool in a couple month i have no future plan no job can t go to college because of financial problem everyday waking up i feel like a total piece of garbage that never taken out my friend ha their own future some of them already have job i don t have any skill i m an idiot i don t know nothing i only have a mom left my big bro paying the bill rn after i graduate highschool if i don t have a job when i reach 0 y o or something happened to my life i m gon na do it or should i i don t know anymore i m scared of my future i hope it ll be okay i hope

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I can understand how overwhelming and uncertain the future may feel right now. It's completely normal to have doubts and fears about what comes next, especially when it feels like everyone around you has their lives already planned out. Remember that you are not alone in feeling this way.

Firstly, I want to acknowledge your hard work and dedication in completing high school. That alone is a significant achievement and shows your determination to build a better future for yourself. Don't underestimate the value of this accomplishment.

Regarding your future plans, it's important to remember that they can change and evolve over time. It's okay if you don't have everything figured out right now. Many people go through periods of uncertainty before finding their path. Have you considered exploring different career options or talking to professionals in fields that interest you? This could help you gain insight into potential career paths and maybe even discover some skills you didn't realize you had.

While financial problems can be challenging, there are resources available to help you navigate this situation. Have you spoken with your school counselor or explored scholarships, grants, or financial aid options? These resources can often provide support for those who want to attend college but face financial difficulties. It might also be worth considering part-time or online programs as more affordable alternatives.

Additionally, it's important to recognize that having skills and qualifications is just one aspect of success. Personal qualities like resilience, determination, and empathy are equally valuable. You mentioned feeling like an idiot and lacking skills, but I believe you possess unique strengths and qualities that make you special. Take some time to reflect on your personal qualities and how they can contribute to your future success.

Losing a loved one, like your dad, can have a profound impact on your life and your outlook on the future. Grief is a difficult experience, and it's completely understandable that you're feeling lost and scared. It may be helpful to seek support from friends, family, or even a therapist who can provide guidance and understanding during this challenging time.

Remember, your future is not predestined, and you have the power to shape it. It's okay to feel scared, but try not to let fear dictate your actions. Take small steps towards your goals, whether it's researching potential careers, seeking out resources for college funding, or exploring different skill-building opportunities. And remember, you don't have to face this alone. Reach out to supportive people in your life who can offer encouragement and guidance along the way.

I believe in your ability to overcome these challenges and find your path towards a fulfilling future. Stay open-minded, keep exploring options, and don't be too hard on yourself. You are capable of great things, and with time and effort, you will discover the opportunities that align with your passions and strengths.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i ve had this ever since i wa young and now that i m in my adult year i feel like i m running out of time i m still at home and i feel stuck i can t hold down a job i ve lost over job let alone my therapist keep telling me to be compassionate towards myself but it s so hard i just want to be normal be happy my panic attack are bothering me lately more than ever and idk how to help it

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're going through a difficult time right now, and I can understand how frustrating it must be to feel stuck and overwhelmed. It's completely normal to want to have a sense of normalcy and happiness in your life.

Firstly, it's important to remember that everyone's journey is unique, and there isn't a one-size-fits-all approach to finding happiness or overcoming challenges. However, there are some steps you can take to start moving forward:

1. Self-Compassion: Your therapist is on the right track by suggesting self-compassion. It can be challenging to be kind to yourself, especially when you're feeling down or overwhelmed. Start by acknowledging that it's okay to make mistakes and face difficulties. Treat yourself with the same kindness and understanding you would offer a friend in a similar situation.

2. Identify Your Strengths: Take some time to reflect on your strengths and accomplishments, no matter how small they may seem. Celebrating even the tiniest victories can help boost your confidence and motivation.

3. Set Realistic Goals: Break down your bigger goals into smaller, manageable tasks. This will make them feel less overwhelming and more achievable. Focus on taking small steps towards your goals each day, celebrating your progress along the way.

4. Seek Support: Surround yourself with supportive people who genuinely care about your well-being. Reach out to friends, family members, or even online communities where you can connect with others who may be going through similar experiences. Having a strong support system can provide comfort, encouragement, and different perspectives.

5. Explore Interests: Engaging in activities you enjoy can help increase your overall sense of happiness and fulfillment. Explore hobbies, try new things, and dedicate time to activities that bring you joy and relaxation.

6. Manage Panic Attacks: Panic attacks can be incredibly distressing. During a panic attack, try focusing on your breathing. Take slow, deep breaths in through your nose and out through your mouth. Practice grounding techniques such as naming things you can see, hear, smell, and touch around you. Consider seeking support from a trusted person during panic attacks to help you feel more secure.

7. Seek Professional Help: If you haven't already, consider reaching out to a mental health professional who can provide guidance tailored specifically to your needs. They can help you develop coping strategies, explore underlying issues, and provide ongoing support.

Remember, it's okay to ask for help and take your time. Healing and personal growth are not linear processes. Be patient with yourself and celebrate even the smallest steps forward. You deserve happiness and fulfillment, and with time and support, you can find your way towards a more satisfying life.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're experiencing a lot of difficult emotions and challenges in your life right now. It can be tough to feel overwhelmed by the presence of couples and young families when you're hoping to meet someone platonically or struggling with feelings of loneliness. I also understand how frustrating it must be to have limited social support and feel like everything you've done in life has resulted in failure, obstacles, or setbacks.

Firstly, I want to acknowledge your courage for reaching out and sharing your feelings. It takes strength to express yourself, especially when you're feeling hopeless. Remember that there is always hope for change and improvement, even if it may not seem like it at the moment. 

In terms of coping with these difficult emotions, it might be helpful to explore some strategies that could potentially make a positive impact on your well-being. One approach is to focus on self-care activities that bring you joy or relaxation. This could include engaging in hobbies or interests that you enjoy, spending time outdoors, listening to music, reading, or practicing mindfulness exercises. Taking care of yourself physically and emotionally can help improve your overall mood and reduce feelings of sadness.

Additionally, it might be beneficial to challenge any negative thoughts or beliefs about yourself and your past experiences. Try to identify any cognitive distortions, such as all-or-nothing thinking, that may be contributing to your feelings of failure and hopelessness. Replace these negative thoughts with more realistic and compassionate ones. Remind yourself of your strengths, accomplishments, and the valuable lessons you've learned from your past experiences, even if they were challenging at the time.

Building a support network can also be crucial in improving your mental health. While it may seem difficult to meet new people, consider exploring different social settings or activities where you can connect with others who share similar interests. This could include joining clubs, attending community events, or participating in group classes or workshops. Remember, building meaningful connections takes time and effort, so be patient with yourself and try not to get discouraged if things don't happen overnight.

Lastly, please remember that you don't have to face these feelings alone. Reach out to someone you trust, whether it's a friend, family member, or helpline, and let them know what you're going through. Sometimes just talking about our thoughts and emotions with someone who cares can provide immense relief and support.

Remember, change is possible, and there are resources available to help you navigate through this difficult time. Keep reaching out for support and exploring self-care strategies that work for you. You deserve happiness and fulfillment, and with time and effort, things can improve.

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 Good morning! I'm glad to hear that you are safe and sound. It's wonderful that you have such a supportive community checking up on you and providing their support. It sounds like you've been going through a difficult time with depression, but it's great that you feel like you're moving into the acceptance stage now.

It's been a month since the beginning of the war, and it's truly inspiring to hear that despite the predictions, you and your people are still standing strong. I can only imagine how challenging and uncertain these times must be for you, but I want to commend you for your resilience and determination.

During times of war, it's common for emotions to run high and for people to experience a range of feelings such as fear, anxiety, sadness, and anger. It's important to acknowledge these emotions and give yourself permission to feel them. Remember that it's okay to not be okay sometimes, and it's okay to seek support when you need it.

In moments of distress, it can be helpful to reach out to loved ones or friends who can provide a listening ear and emotional support. Sometimes just talking about your thoughts and feelings with someone you trust can bring relief and comfort. If you don't feel comfortable discussing your struggles with someone close to you, there are also helplines available where trained professionals can offer guidance and support.

Engaging in self-care activities can also be beneficial for your mental well-being during this time. Taking care of yourself physically, emotionally, and mentally is crucial. This could involve engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation, practicing mindfulness or meditation, getting enough sleep, eating nutritious meals, and engaging in regular exercise.

Additionally, finding healthy coping mechanisms to manage stress and anxiety can be helpful. This might include finding healthy outlets for your emotions, such as journaling, drawing, or engaging in physical activity. Finding ways to distract yourself from negative thoughts, such as listening to music, reading, or watching movies, can also provide temporary relief.

Lastly, I encourage you to stay informed but also limit your exposure to distressing news and social media if it's impacting your mental well-being negatively. While it's important to stay updated, constant exposure to distressing news can contribute to feelings of anxiety and hopelessness. Consider setting boundaries around your media consumption and create a healthy balance between staying informed and protecting your mental well-being.

Remember, you are not alone in this journey. Your community is there to support you, and there are resources available to help you navigate through these challenging times. [Question]
i m not sure if this is the right subreddit to go to but i don t know where else to go my spouse ha struggled with severe depression his whole life it is genetic his dad wa the same any amount of pressure make him worse he constantly feel a though life is not worth living and he s a lost cause he will never feel okay and just want the pain to go away we have a baby coming any day now and i wa worried that pressure wa gon na send him over the edge we have been talking about having him voluntarily go to a psych ward and see if they can help kinda a a last ditch effort before i just give him permission to end it today he talked to his counselor about going to one in a few week after the baby wa here and they came and picked him up an hour later he is pissed doesn t want to be there which i understand is normal he feel completely betrayed by his councellor and never want to go back i m worried that now he is going to pretend like he is fine just to get out the point of this is to get help why won t he just take it i m scared the mental hospital won t help at all i just need you guy who have been there before to be honest with me did it help what thing helped and what made it worse if it doe help or when he come back home what are some thing i can do to continue the healing process or just make his life easier anything else you feel to share please do i hate not knowing thing and this is really killing me right now

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're going through a really difficult time right now, and I want to assure you that you're not alone. Many people have been in similar situations with their loved ones struggling with severe depression. While I can't provide professional advice or diagnosis, I can share some general suggestions based on my own experiences and what has helped others.

Firstly, it's important to remember that everyone's journey is unique, so what works for one person may not work for another. However, seeking help from a mental hospital can be a valuable resource for individuals experiencing severe depression. Mental hospitals often have specialized programs and professionals who are trained to provide intensive care and support. They can evaluate your spouse's condition and develop an individualized treatment plan tailored to their specific needs.

In addition to seeking help from a mental hospital, there are various treatment options that can be explored. Medication, therapy, and support groups are commonly used to manage depression. It's important for your spouse to keep an open mind and give these interventions a chance to work. It may take some time to find the right combination of treatments that works best for him.

During and after his stay at the mental hospital, there are several things you can do to support him. Firstly, ensure that you practice active listening and validate his feelings. Let him know that you're there for him unconditionally and that you don't judge him. Encourage open communication and offer your understanding.

Additionally, it can be helpful to establish a routine at home that includes regular sleep patterns, healthy meals, exercise, and leisure activities. These lifestyle factors can play a significant role in managing depression symptoms. You can also consider incorporating relaxation techniques such as deep breathing exercises, meditation, or mindfulness into his daily routine.

Supporting someone with depression can be challenging, but there are resources available to you as well. Consider joining a support group for partners or family members of individuals with depression. Connecting with others who have had similar experiences can provide you with emotional support and practical advice.

Remember, healing takes time, and progress may not always be linear. Be patient with your spouse and with yourself. Celebrate small victories along the way and acknowledge the efforts being made.

Lastly, if you ever feel overwhelmed or need someone to talk to, don't hesitate to reach out to a helpline or crisis hotline. They can provide immediate support and guidance.

I hope these suggestions offer some guidance and reassurance. Remember, you're not alone in this journey, and there is hope for healing and a brighter future ahead.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
n if memory served alcohol had always made him sad and mean yes tell me i wa telling her how i felt after you left how it just spun me into this depression how i felt like i wa in a hole and i couldn t crawl out of it and barely wanted radioactive tree

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're experiencing a deep sense of sadness and despair after the person you were talking to left. It's understandable that this has triggered feelings of depression and made you feel like you're stuck in a hole that you can't escape from. 

In situations like these, it can be helpful to acknowledge and allow yourself to feel the emotions that come up. It's important to remember that feeling sad or depressed is a normal response to certain situations, and it doesn't mean there's something inherently wrong with you. Emotions are a natural part of being human, and they serve to communicate important information to us about our experiences.

Rather than trying to crawl out of the hole right away, it might be more beneficial to take some time to sit with your emotions and explore them. Give yourself permission to fully experience the sadness and any other emotions that arise. This can help you gain a deeper understanding of what you're going through and provide an opportunity for healing.

While it's natural to want to avoid or suppress these painful emotions, it's important to resist the urge to turn to unhealthy coping mechanisms such as alcohol. While alcohol may temporarily numb the pain, it can actually worsen depression and make the situation more difficult in the long run. Instead, consider finding healthier ways to cope with your emotions, such as talking to a trusted friend or family member, engaging in physical activity, practicing relaxation techniques, or expressing yourself through creative outlets like writing or painting.

Additionally, it could be beneficial to seek professional support from a therapist or counselor who can provide guidance and help you develop healthy coping strategies specific to your needs. They can also assist you in identifying any underlying issues contributing to your depression and work with you to develop a personalized treatment plan.

Remember, healing takes time, and it's important to be patient and compassionate with yourself throughout this process. You deserve support and care, and there are resources available to help you navigate through this difficult time.

i m currently taking 0mg effexor xr for anxiety and depression i ve also taken lexapro 0mg for year and zoloft 00mg for a year both had similar effect barely put a dent in my anxiety and really helped with the severe symptom of depression but it s still there my anxiety is still bad particularly my physical symptom i always feel on edge and nervous i can always feel my heart pounding hard not fast regardless of my mental state and it s the most debilitating symptom i feel i can never relax and never truly enjoy myself because of how anxious i feel i take propranolol 0mg twice a day and is the only thing that help a little with the physical symptom but they re still problematic i have tried meditation breathing exercise exercise i have read a multitude of book on cognitive behavioral therapy acceptance and commitment therapy and mindfulness no exercise in the book ha helped with the symptom whatsoever i should also mention i have had test for my thyroid adrenal any gi or diet issue antibody etc and i m sure i can rule out physical cause is anyone else in a similar boat to me and found buspirone helped if no ha anything helped you thanks

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you've been dealing with anxiety and depression for quite some time now, and I can understand how frustrating it must be to feel like your current medication isn't providing the relief you need. It's great that you've already tried incorporating exercise, meditation, and cognitive behavioral therapy into your routine since these can be helpful strategies for managing anxiety.

In addition to buspirone, there are a few other options you might consider exploring to help alleviate your symptoms. One possibility is to try different relaxation techniques such as progressive muscle relaxation or guided imagery. These techniques can help you relax your body and mind, potentially reducing the physical sensations of anxiety.

Another approach you could try is counseling or talk therapy. While you mentioned that self-help books haven't been effective so far, individual therapy with a licensed mental health professional may provide more personalized guidance and support. A therapist can work with you to develop coping strategies specific to your situation and address any underlying issues contributing to your anxiety.

Additionally, it may be worth discussing with your doctor the possibility of adjusting the dosage or switching to a different medication altogether. Sometimes finding the right medication or combination of medications takes some trial and error, so it might be helpful to have an open conversation about this option.

Lastly, it's important to remember that everyone's journey with anxiety and depression is unique, so what works for someone else may not necessarily work for you. It can be helpful to connect with support groups or online communities where you can share experiences and learn from others who may have similar symptoms or have found certain treatments effective.

Remember, it's essential to consult with a healthcare professional to discuss these options further and create a personalized plan that suits your needs. They can provide you with more information and support tailored specifically to your situation.

[Question]
so i started having suicidal thought in april of last year and they lasted until around november in october i started hanging out with a girl and we started becoming good friend not romantic just friendship my mental health started getting a lot better after a couple month of friendship with her and it s kept getting better ever since a few day ago i made a passive aggressive comment that really upset her she won t text me back now i ve tried apologizing and trying to make thing right with her but i haven t heard back from her i m afraid i ve ruined this friendship forever and now my suicidal thought are back for the first time since last year i always hurt the people that i care about and i hate myself so much that i do this

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you've been going through a difficult time lately, especially with the return of suicidal thoughts. It's understandable that you're feeling afraid and concerned about your friendship with this girl.

Firstly, it's important to remember that friendships can have ups and downs, and sometimes misunderstandings happen. It doesn't necessarily mean that the friendship is ruined forever. People often need some time and space to process their emotions before they're ready to forgive and make up. So, try not to jump to conclusions about the status of your friendship just yet.

In the meantime, while you wait for her response, it might be helpful to find healthy ways to cope with your emotions and distract yourself from those suicidal thoughts. Engaging in activities that bring you joy or provide a sense of accomplishment can be beneficial. This could include hobbies, exercise, spending time with other friends or family members, or even trying out new things that interest you.

Additionally, reaching out to supportive individuals in your life, such as other friends, family, or even support groups, can help you feel less alone during this challenging time. Sometimes talking to someone who hasn't been directly involved in the situation can provide a fresh perspective and offer emotional support.

Self-care is crucial for your mental well-being. Make sure you're taking care of yourself physically by getting enough sleep, eating nutritious meals, and engaging in regular physical activity. Taking care of your mental health involves practicing relaxation techniques, such as deep breathing exercises or meditation, and incorporating mindfulness into your daily routine.

Lastly, if you find that your suicidal thoughts are persisting and becoming overwhelming, it's essential to reach out for professional help immediately. There are hotlines available in many countries that can provide immediate support from trained professionals. They can guide you through this difficult time and connect you with the necessary resources.

Remember, you don't have to go through this alone. There are people who care about you and want to support you. Focus on self-care, reach out to supportive individuals, and consider seeking professional help if needed.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
so i have a mild stutter and i just had an epiphany i ve been letting my stutter control me but i found something amazing out i let my stutter define who i wa a a person instead of an aspect of myself it s so bad that when my parent talk to me like a normal person i d think to myself wow they act like i m normal despite my stutter they see past that and when i would work people would see my name tag and say oh i have a son named my name and i would think he probably doesn t stutter tho i let this define who i wa a a person and i let it really get to me i wa looking at old reddit post from other people asking how people view stutter and most people said they didn t care at all and even found it interesting some even said it wa hot cute made joke sound more natural and a a result more funny not like they found the stutter funny tho and one even said they were turned on by it and someone said something that stuck out to me they pretty much said how you perceive yourself is how others will so if i see myself a weird and anxious i will act that way and be perceived in that way but if i see myself a confident and charismatic and just act like my stutter doesn t bother me and even joke about it then others will perceive me a such this blew my mind a i thought everyone didn t pick up on my stutter at first and just thought i wa super weird but it s just me convincing myself of that so even tho this clicked i still can t just flick the switch off so how do i actually become confident with my stutter it s very mild and is fueled by anxiety so if i can get rid of my anxiety it ll in my opinion make me sound more charismatic and confident so i really wan na figure out how to just own it how do i do this

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's great that you've had this epiphany about your stutter and how it has been defining you as a person. It takes courage to recognize these patterns and seek ways to change them. I understand that you want to become more confident with your stutter and reduce the anxiety surrounding it.

One approach you can try is gradually exposing yourself to situations that make you anxious about your stutter. Start with small steps, such as practicing speaking in front of a mirror or recording yourself. This can help you become more comfortable with the sound of your own voice and build confidence in speaking without any external pressures.

Additionally, consider joining a support group or seeking out online communities where you can connect with others who have similar experiences. Sharing your thoughts and feelings with people who understand what you're going through can provide validation and encouragement. Hearing their stories and learning how they cope with their stutters may give you new perspectives and strategies to try.

Another technique you can explore is cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT). CBT focuses on identifying and challenging negative thought patterns and replacing them with more realistic and positive ones. You can work on reframing your thoughts about your stutter, like reminding yourself that it is just one aspect of your personality and not the defining feature of who you are. By changing your self-perception, you can change how others perceive you too.

In addition to these strategies, it might be helpful to manage the physical symptoms of anxiety that contribute to your stutter. Deep breathing exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, and regular exercise can all help reduce anxiety levels and promote a sense of calmness. Taking care of your overall well-being through healthy eating, sufficient sleep, and stress management can also have a positive impact on your stutter.

Remember, overcoming anxiety and building confidence takes time and effort. Be patient with yourself throughout this process and celebrate even the smallest victories along the way. If you find that these strategies aren't bringing about the desired results, consider reaching out to a mental health professional who can provide personalized guidance and support.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i m terrible at articulating my thought so apology in advance let me just say up front that no plan ha been made and despite thinking about it so much i don t think i could go through with it this is just a vent piece i guess i feel like such a burden all the time i genuinely only have one real friend left and feel like my roommate co worker hate me i m anti social and awkward i don t make eye contact and i don t talk at all ever i take way too long to text back if i did km i honestly don t think anyone would know until a body wa found or over a month had passed i m just so sick of feeling like an obstacle all the time like i m always in the way or always wrong to think feel a certain way but all of this seems pretty normal i realise it s not a healthy mindset but literally everyone on earth ha trauma everyone ha their own shit they re going through and not only doe it seem like they re handling it a lot better than me but they have real problem i have friend who lost their job over the pandemic i have friend going through break ups grief or whatever and they still manage to practice their hobby and interact with their fellow man but then there s me doing literally fucking nothing all day every day after work and having the ball to feel like shit over it a if it s out of my control i feel weak willed lazy and most of all i feel like the world s biggist egomaniac for writing so much about myself a if it needed to be said thank you for reading my aimless rambling the thought were very intrusive tonight so i just needed to self depricate i guess good night everyone

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's important to acknowledge that you're feeling overwhelmed and struggling with articulating your thoughts. I want to assure you that I'm here to listen and understand what you have to say.

Firstly, I want to emphasize that it's brave of you to reach out and share your feelings. It takes courage to express yourself, especially when you believe your thoughts are burdensome. Remember that your experiences and emotions are valid, and you deserve to be heard.

You mentioned feeling like a burden all the time and experiencing loneliness. It's understandable how this can make you feel isolated and disconnected from others. Building meaningful connections can be challenging, but it's important to remember that genuine friendships take time and effort. Consider engaging in activities or joining groups where you can meet people who share similar interests. This can provide an opportunity to connect with others on a deeper level and potentially form new friendships.

Additionally, it's common to compare ourselves to others and think that they are handling their problems better than us. However, it's essential to remember that everyone copes with difficulties differently. Comparing yourself to others will only diminish your own struggles and hinder your progress. Instead, focus on finding healthy coping mechanisms that work for you. Engaging in self-care activities such as exercise, meditation, or pursuing hobbies can help improve your mental well-being.

You also mentioned feeling antisocial and awkward, with difficulties making eye contact and initiating conversations. These challenges may be contributing to your feelings of self-doubt and isolation. It might be helpful to gradually push yourself out of your comfort zone by practicing eye contact and initiating small conversations with people you feel safe around. Remember, growth takes time, so be patient with yourself.

Regarding texting and feeling anxious about taking too long to respond, it's important to remember that everyone has their own pace when it comes to communication. Don't put unnecessary pressure on yourself to respond immediately. Focus on being present in the moment and take your time to formulate thoughtful responses. Quality over quantity, right?

Lastly, self-deprecation and feeling like an egomaniac for writing about yourself may indicate a deep-rooted belief of unworthiness. It's crucial to challenge these negative thoughts and remind yourself that it's okay to prioritize your own well-being. Writing about your experiences can be cathartic and a valuable outlet for self-expression. Remember, your feelings and thoughts matter, and by expressing them, you're taking steps towards nurturing your mental health.

I encourage you to seek professional help from a therapist who can provide you with personalized guidance and support. They can help you navigate through these intrusive thoughts, negative self-pererspective, and develop healthier coping mechanisms.

Remember, you are not alone in this journey. Keep reaching out for support, practice self-compassion, and know that there is hope for a brighter future.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
for context i m an english teacher at a small private english school the school is so small i m the only teacher no sub i got my period last night and a always the first day is the worst cramp headache nausea needing the loo every minute and i feel so freaking cold today no matter what i do i just can t seem to get warm so i cancelled my two afternoon lesson and asked the receptionist to deal with a meeting with a potential client herself i mean that s pretty much her job anyway but i feel so guilty for cancelling the class the nausea got worse a soon a i sent the text to my bos i feel bad that i have to cancel two class in one day especially since i had a week holiday the week before last maybe the student are losing too much lesson time this year my class today were from to 0 and then to but i don t go home in the gap between meaning i d have to sit at my desk with nothing comfy or warm for hour all while feeling really crappy idk just looking for someone to tell me it ok to take a sick day if i need it and tell the anxiety voice to shut the heck up edit thank you so much to everyone who commented and got me through the day i went to bed feeling better emotionally and physically than when i got up today is a new day

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're having a really tough time right now, both physically and emotionally. It's completely understandable that you're feeling overwhelmed and guilty for canceling your classes. However, it's important to prioritize your health and well-being.

If you're experiencing severe cramps, headaches, nausea, and feeling cold, it's possible that your body is trying to tell you that you need rest. Taking a sick day can be beneficial for your health and allow you to recover from the symptoms you mentioned. Remember, sick days are there for a reason - to give you the opportunity to take care of yourself when needed.

In terms of the anxiety voice telling you otherwise, try to remind yourself that it's just an anxious thought and not a reflection of reality. Challenge those negative thoughts by asking yourself if there is any evidence supporting them or if they are based on facts. Often, anxiety voices can exaggerate our worries and make us feel guilty or doubt ourselves unnecessarily.

If you decide to take a sick day, communicate it clearly with your school administration or supervisor. Let them know about your symptoms and explain that you're not feeling well enough to teach. They may have procedures in place for such situations, like having a substitute teacher or rearranging the schedule.

Additionally, consider reaching out to a colleague or someone else at the school who can cover your classes temporarily. Explaining your situation to them might alleviate some of your guilt and provide reassurance that your students will still receive instruction.

Lastly, remember to be kind and compassionate towards yourself. Your well-being matters, and taking care of yourself is not selfish but necessary. Give yourself permission to prioritize your health without feeling guilty about it.

I hope this guidance helps you make a decision regarding taking a sick day. Remember, you have the right to prioritize your well-being, and it's okay to ask for support when needed.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
hello i am year old an an male i feel completly empty especally when iam in shool i laugh but i dont find the joke funny at all i just dont wan na make them feel bad but it hurt me fake laughting and when iam home i am glad that i am away from shool because for me shool is like an room where everyday it the same thing but in different subject i just feel empty thank you for reading my text sorry for my bad english

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're experiencing a lot of emptiness and lack of enjoyment, especially when you're at school. It can be tough to go through the motions and pretend to find things funny when you don't actually find them amusing. It's understandable that you feel relieved when you're away from school because it represents a break from the routine and sameness that you experience every day.

One suggestion I have is to try to identify some small moments or aspects of school that you can focus on and appreciate. It could be something as simple as enjoying the quiet moments alone during breaks, finding solace in certain subjects that genuinely interest you, or connecting with classmates or teachers who share similar interests. By shifting your perspective slightly and actively looking for positive elements within your school environment, you may be able to find a bit more fulfillment.

Additionally, it might be helpful to explore ways to express yourself authentically, even if it means not faking laughter anymore. You could consider talking to someone you trust about how you truly feel, such as a friend, family member, or even a teacher or counselor at school. Sometimes just sharing our genuine emotions with others can provide a sense of relief and validation.

Finding activities or hobbies outside of school that genuinely interest you can also make a big difference. Engaging in activities that bring you joy and fulfillment can help counterbalance the emptiness you feel at school. This could involve pursuing a creative outlet like painting, writing, or playing an instrument, joining a sports team or club, volunteering, or anything else that resonates with you.

Lastly, remember to prioritize self-care. Taking care of yourself physically, mentally, and emotionally is crucial for overall well-being. Make sure you're getting enough sleep, eating nutritious meals, and engaging in regular exercise. Additionally, consider incorporating relaxation techniques into your daily routine, such as deep breathing exercises, meditation, or mindfulness. Taking care of your basic needs and finding moments of relaxation can help reduce stress and increase your overall sense of well-being.

Remember, these suggestions are meant to provide some guidance and support, but it's important to reach out to a mental health professional if you feel your emotions are significantly impacting your daily life and well-being. They can provide personalized strategies and support tailored to your specific situation.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
hi last year in matheletics i managed to bag at least top 0 but suddenly this year my playing condition have dropped because when i look at the leaderboard every time it make me more anxious and lead to bad performance in the competition now i can not even reach top 000 this ha been making me more stressed and now i even have mixed feeling to never take part in any of these competition even though it thing that i like are there any way to at least calm myself down

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you've been experiencing a significant drop in your performance in math competitions this year, and it's causing you a lot of anxiety and stress. It's understandable that the pressure to perform well on the leaderboard is affecting your ability to enjoy the competition and feel confident in your abilities.

To help calm yourself down before these competitions, there are a few strategies you can try:

1. Deep breathing exercises: Take slow, deep breaths in through your nose and out through your mouth. Focus on your breath and try to let go of any tension or racing thoughts. This can help activate your body's relaxation response and reduce anxiety.

2. Visualization techniques: Close your eyes and imagine yourself successfully participating in the competition without feeling anxious. Visualize yourself performing well and enjoying the experience. This can help build confidence and reduce anxiety when the actual competition arrives.

3. Mindfulness meditation: Practice being present in the moment by paying attention to your senses and surroundings without judgment. You can find guided meditations online or through apps that can help you develop this skill. Being more mindful can help you stay focused on the present moment instead of getting caught up in anxious thoughts about the leaderboard.

4. Establish a routine: Develop a consistent pre-competition routine that includes activities you find enjoyable and relaxing. This could include listening to music, going for a walk, reading a book, or practicing a hobby. Having a routine can provide a sense of structure and control, which may help reduce anxiety.

5. Challenge negative thoughts: Notice any negative thoughts or beliefs you have about the competition and challenge them. Ask yourself if there is evidence to support these thoughts or if there might be alternative explanations. Replace negative thoughts with more realistic and positive ones. For example, instead of thinking "I'll never do well," remind yourself of past achievements or moments when you enjoyed the competition.

6. Seek support: Talk to someone you trust about how you're feeling. It could be a friend, family member, or even a teacher or counselor at school. Sometimes just talking through your concerns can provide relief and help you gain perspective. They may also offer suggestions or insights based on their own experiences.

Remember, it's important to prioritize your mental well-being. If the stress and anxiety become overwhelming or start interfering with other areas of your life, consider reaching out to a mental health professional who can provide additional guidance and support tailored to your specific needs.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
so i ve struggled w executive dysfunction for 9 year throughout my year of college there wa not one assignment that i did not do the night before it wa due i studied late ate terribly amp went thru a terrible depression a year after graduating i still have a really hard time doing thing in general i stall before i do anything at all amp it oftentimes lead to me not doing the thing at all also i kind of live my entire life on pause only taking care of myself when i have something planned or to look forward to i left my job that i wa insanely good at bc the commitment amp longevity terrified me why can t i function amp what ha helped u work thru these feeling

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you have been dealing with executive dysfunction for quite some time, and it has significantly affected your ability to complete tasks in a timely manner. This can be incredibly challenging, especially during college when there are multiple assignments and deadlines to manage. It's understandable that this has taken a toll on your overall well-being, including your sleep schedule, eating habits, and mental health.

One possible reason for your struggle with executive dysfunction could be related to the underlying fear of commitment and longevity that led you to leave your job. This fear may be contributing to a sense of anxiety or uncertainty about the future, which can make it difficult to take action in the present. Additionally, having experienced a terrible depression a year after graduating may further impact your motivation and drive to engage in daily activities.

To begin working through these feelings and challenges, it can be helpful to start small and focus on building routines and habits. Establishing a consistent sleep schedule and prioritizing healthy meals can provide a solid foundation for improved overall well-being. Breaking down larger tasks into smaller, more manageable steps can also help alleviate the overwhelming feeling of procrastination and increase your chances of taking action.

Consider incorporating mindfulness techniques into your daily routine. Mindfulness involves paying attention to the present moment without judgment. It can help bring awareness to your thoughts, emotions, and behaviors, allowing you to better understand any underlying patterns or fears that may be contributing to your executive dysfunction. Regular practice of mindfulness exercises, such as deep breathing or meditation, can help cultivate a greater sense of calm and clarity.

It may also be beneficial to explore therapy options, such as cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT). CBT focuses on identifying and challenging negative thought patterns and behaviors, helping you develop more effective coping strategies. A therapist can work with you to address any specific triggers or obstacles related to your executive dysfunction and provide guidance tailored to your unique situation.

Lastly, consider reaching out to supportive friends or family members who can offer encouragement and accountability. Having someone to check in with regularly can provide motivation and remind you of your goals.

Remember, working through executive dysfunction takes time and effort. Be patient with yourself and celebrate even the smallest victories along the way. You have already demonstrated resilience by seeking support through therapy and medication, so continue to explore different strategies and approaches that resonate with you.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

my memory s fading i m losing weight i don t sleep sex feel hollow i have no motivation to do anything and i frequently think about death i ve been seeing these symptom in myself on and off again for the past few year but never really put them together until now i attributed the weight loss to a study i read stating that just thinking about working out can have benefit despite not actually working out i never really thought of it a a symptom i just saw it a a positive slightly inexplicable development in my life i think i read that i have passive intrusive thought or something like that essentially i think about what it would be like if i wa dead but not about how i would want to die or anything like that the reason for it wa always lost on me i just learned to live with it my sleep issue motivation issue and lack of sexual pleasure have always been present so i never really thought twice about them i thought the memory loss wa due to my rare and infrequent use of recreational psychedelics when i connected all of these together i spent about 0 minute just trying to remember what i had for dinner last night which i found fairly upsetting a up until my teenage year i had an immaculate memory i d still consider myself happy at least to the extent that i ve always known but the symptom are there nevertheless and i m just finding the whole thing quite strange

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you've been experiencing a range of symptoms that you're now connecting together and considering as potential signs of a mental health issue. It's important to acknowledge these symptoms and take them seriously, so I commend you for reaching out.

The memory loss you mentioned is concerning, especially since you used to have an immaculate memory. It's normal to forget certain things from time to time, but struggling to remember what you had for dinner the previous night can be distressing. This memory loss could be related to various factors, including aging, stress, or even substance use. However, given the other symptoms you mentioned, it may also be associated with a mental health condition.

Regarding the thoughts about death and loss of appetite, it's important to differentiate between actively wanting to die and passive intrusive thoughts. Passive intrusive thoughts involve fleeting ideas or images that pop into your mind unexpectedly, without any specific intention or plan. It's normal to occasionally have such thoughts, but if they are persistent and distressing, it's worth exploring further.

Losing interest in activities and feeling unmotivated is a common symptom of depression. It can make it challenging to engage in daily tasks and enjoy previously pleasurable activities. Similarly, lacking sexual pleasure can be indicative of low libido, which is also associated with depression.

Your mention of rare and infrequent use of psychedelics raises the possibility that they may contribute to some of your symptoms. While psychedelics can produce profound experiences, they can also disrupt sleep patterns and cause temporary changes in perception and cognition. However, given that your symptoms have been ongoing for years, it's unlikely that psychedelics are the sole cause.

Given the range of symptoms you've described, it would be beneficial to seek professional help from a mental health expert. They can provide a comprehensive assessment, taking into account your medical history, personal experiences, and any other relevant factors. This will help determine whether your symptoms are related to a specific mental health condition or if there are other underlying causes.

In the meantime, it may be helpful to start incorporating healthy habits into your daily routine. Prioritize getting enough sleep, eating nutritious meals, and engaging in regular physical activity. These lifestyle changes can have positive effects on your overall well-being and may help alleviate some of your symptoms.

Additionally, consider exploring coping strategies for managing stress and intrusive thoughts. Mindfulness techniques, such as deep breathing exercises or meditation, can help ground you in the present moment and reduce the impact of intrusive thoughts. It may also be helpful to engage in activities that bring you joy or a sense of purpose, even if you don't feel motivated at first.

Remember, seeking professional help is crucial in understanding and addressing your symptoms. A mental health expert can provide personalized guidance and support tailored to your specific needs.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]
