i m starting a new job tomorrow and i m extremely anxious about it i m excited to start this new chapter but i just wish i didn t feel so nauseous right now i ve come really far in overcoming my anxiety but i ve taken everything slowly one baby step at a time this is a huge step the only job i ve had in the past year is instacarting grocery shop amp delivery that i started month ago i did everything at my own pace day a week and maybe a few order a day this job i m starting is hour shift time a week i shouldn t have set myself up for so much but i need to start working towards my career a a dog groomer and this bathing job is an incredible opportunity to do so my living situation is changing soon in that i will need to bring money to the table so i didn t have much of a choice the worst part is i can t actually bathe any dog until i ve learned from the other groomer how to do it which will take time so i worry that the day will go by really slowly because i won t even be doing anything or getting paid until i am ready to start bathing which i don t know how long that will take a friend of mine who work there in the pet store not in the grooming room pulled a lot of string for me with the bos a well my entire family and boyfriend family know i m starting tomorrow and are so happy to see me finally starting to do something meaningful they ve all had a problem with my not working for year because of my anxiety i just feel like not only for my sake but for everyone else s sake i can not screw this up i feel like i m throwing myself into the deep end and hoping i can swim

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 Starting a new job can be both exciting and anxiety-inducing, especially when it's a significant step towards your career goals. It's completely normal to feel nervous on your first day, but I understand that the physical symptoms of anxiety, such as nausea, can make it more challenging.

Firstly, I want to acknowledge your bravery and determination in overcoming your anxiety. Taking things slowly, one baby step at a time, is an excellent approach that allows you to build confidence and gradually increase your comfort zone. This new job may indeed feel like a big step, but remember that you've already come so far in overcoming your anxiety, and this is another opportunity for growth.

It's understandable that not being able to bathe any dogs right away is causing you to worry about the day going by slowly and not getting paid until you're ready. However, try to reframe this waiting period as a chance to learn and observe from the other groomer. You can use this time to familiarize yourself with the environment, ask questions, and gain valuable insights into the grooming process. Additionally, consider using this time to complete any necessary training or certification required for the job.

Regarding your living situation changing soon, it's great that you recognize the need to contribute financially. This new job is an incredible opportunity to learn and grow as a dog groomer, which can lead to a fulfilling career. Remember that everyone has to start somewhere, and this temporary waiting period will be worth it in the long run.

Feeling the pressure from your family and boyfriend's family to succeed in this job is understandable, but it's important to remember that they want what's best for you. Instead of viewing it as pressure, try to see their support as motivation to succeed. Use their excitement and encouragement as fuel to propel yourself forward.

Lastly, it's completely normal to feel like you're throwing yourself into the deep end and hoping to swim. Starting a new job always comes with uncertainties, but remember that you have already proven your ability to adapt and overcome challenges. Believe in yourself and your capabilities. You have prepared for this moment, and even if there are obstacles along the way, you have demonstrated that you can handle them.

In conclusion, it's completely normal to feel anxious about starting your new job, especially when there are high expectations and a sense of urgency due to your living situation. Remember that this is an opportunity for growth, and use the waiting period before bathing dogs as a chance to learn and observe. Take the pressure from your loved ones as motivation rather than a burden. Lastly, remind yourself of your past successes in overcoming anxiety and trust that you have the ability to adapt and succeed in this new chapter.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i feel like wanting to die why do i not have friend i feel soo empty lonely i mean i do have a lot of people i talk to on a daily basis but for some reason i feel the need to always have someone almost all the time with me like if i stay alone for hour i feel lonely it is weird i just wish to be happy i don t want to kill myself

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're experiencing a lot of emotions right now and it can be really tough to feel lonely and empty even when you have people around you. It's completely normal to want to have someone with you or to feel lonely when you're alone for extended periods of time.

One thing that might help is to try and identify activities or hobbies that bring you joy or make you feel fulfilled. Engaging in these activities can help distract you from negative thoughts and provide a sense of purpose and satisfaction. It could be something as simple as reading a book, going for a walk, painting, or listening to music.

Another suggestion is to consider reaching out to others and building deeper connections. While having a large number of people to talk to on a daily basis is great, it's important to also have a smaller group of close friends who you can confide in and spend quality time with. This might involve being more intentional about making plans with others, initiating conversations, or joining groups or clubs where you can meet like-minded individuals.

Additionally, practicing self-care is crucial for your mental well-being. Make sure you're taking care of yourself physically by getting enough sleep, eating nutritious meals, and engaging in regular exercise. Taking care of your physical health can have a positive impact on your emotional well-being.

If you find that these suggestions aren't helping alleviate your feelings of emptiness and loneliness, it may be beneficial to seek support from a mental health professional. They can provide you with additional guidance, coping strategies, and help you explore any underlying issues that may be contributing to your current state.

Remember, you don't have to go through this alone. There are resources available to support you and help you find happiness.

[Question]
i live at home and i love my parent but i m beginning to spiral after an incident month ago i ve been profoundly depressed and stressed out i wa renting but moved back home to save money while trying to get myself back in order especially because my med stopped working i m an only child and my parent have no friend so now that i m back home all they want to do is constantly talk to me i already have poor sleep a it is but it could be am and my dad will shake me awake to talk about a car or his work day or my mom will come in and talk to me about my finance or why i never talk to her about my mental health one time recently i had been woken up so abruptly i could feel my entire nervous system jolt like i had been struck by lighting even thinking about it make my entire body randomly hurt i never get to be alone anymore i try to get alone time but i never get it for more than a couple hour at an time bc of the sleep deprivation i hallucinate now i hear and see thing i honestly wish somthing would happen to me and it would just all end life s so stressful and the little thing aren t fun anymore i hate myself i hate everything i used to love nothing fun anymore what s the fucking point

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're going through a really tough time right now, and I want to offer some guidance and suggestions. It's important to remember that I'm not a mental health professional, but I'll do my best to provide support.

Firstly, it's understandable that living at home and constantly being interrupted can feel overwhelming, especially when you're already dealing with depression and stress. It seems like you need some space to process your emotions and recharge. Have you tried having an open and honest conversation with your parents about how their constant talk affects your mental health? Expressing your needs calmly and assertively might help them understand the impact it has on you.

Additionally, it's concerning to hear that you're experiencing sleep deprivation and hallucinations. These symptoms can be quite distressing. It may be helpful to establish a consistent sleep routine and create a relaxing bedtime routine to improve the quality of your sleep. You could also consider using relaxation techniques such as deep breathing exercises or guided meditation before bed to help calm your mind.

Regarding the hallucinations, it could be helpful to determine if there are any specific triggers or patterns associated with them. Are they happening during certain times of day or in particular situations? If you notice any consistent patterns, you might want to discuss this with a healthcare professional who can provide further guidance and support.

Feeling the need to isolate yourself and having thoughts of self-harm is a sign that you may be struggling more intensively with your mental health. It's crucial to reach out for support during these times. Consider confiding in someone you trust, such as a close friend or family member, and let them know what you're going through. Sometimes just having someone to talk to can make a big difference.

In terms of coping strategies, it's great that you've already tried journaling and listening to music. While these activities may not provide the solitude you desire right now, there are other coping techniques you can explore. Engaging in regular physical exercise, even if it's just going for a walk, can help release endorphins and improve your mood. Additionally, practicing relaxation techniques during the day, such as deep breathing exercises or mindfulness, can help reduce stress and anxiety.

Remember, it's important to reach out for professional help if you haven't already done so. They can provide you with the appropriate guidance and support tailored to your specific situation.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

i m not the same person and i didn t like the person i wa before that so it s not even considered a loss but now i just stopped caring i genuinely stopped caring and it make me want to hate myself but the thing is im too exhausted to even hate myself i just feel like nothing just an empty space where a human used to be i ve stopped caring and it scare me i know the final step is when you stop caring and im at this step i don t care to pursue my passion or talent because whats the point why live a live when i will be forgotten why wa i even made like why even bother trying what even is the point in living if i can t be bothered to try

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're going through a difficult time right now, and I want to provide some guidance and suggestions for you. It's important to remember that everyone's journey is unique, and what works for one person may not work for another. However, here are some suggestions that might help:

1. Start by acknowledging your feelings: It's understandable that you may be feeling lost, empty, and exhausted. Give yourself permission to feel these emotions without judgment. Remember that it's okay to not be okay sometimes.

2. Seek support from loved ones: Reach out to trusted friends or family members who can offer a listening ear and emotional support. Sometimes, just talking about your thoughts and feelings with someone who cares can provide relief and validation.

3. Consider professional help: If you haven't already, it might be beneficial to seek professional help from a therapist or counselor. They can provide you with the necessary tools and strategies to cope with your emotions and thoughts more effectively.

4. Explore self-care practices: Engage in activities that bring you joy and relaxation. This could include hobbies, exercise, spending time in nature, or practicing mindfulness and meditation. Taking care of yourself physically and emotionally is crucial during this challenging time.

5. Reflect on your values and passions: While you may have lost interest in pursuing your passion or talent, take some time to reflect on why they were important to you in the first place. What about them resonated with you? Understanding your values and what brings you fulfillment can help you regain motivation and purpose.

6. Set small achievable goals: Instead of focusing on the bigger picture, break down your goals into smaller, manageable steps. Celebrate each accomplishment along the way, no matter how small. This can help build momentum and give you a sense of achievement.

7. Challenge negative thoughts: Notice any negative thoughts or self-critical beliefs that may be contributing to your feelings of hopelessness. Ask yourself if there is evidence to support these thoughts, and try to find alternative perspectives or more balanced interpretations.

8. Practice self-compassion: Treat yourself with kindness and understanding, just as you would treat a close friend. Remind yourself that it's okay to make mistakes and have setbacks. Be patient with yourself and practice self-compassion when you're feeling overwhelmed.

Remember, these suggestions are not meant to replace professional help but rather offer some guidance and support. Take care of yourself and reach out for help when needed.

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're going through a really tough time right now, and I want you to know that you're not alone. It's understandable that you feel discouraged and lack motivation, especially when faced with the judgment and discouragement from others or your own self-doubt.

Firstly, it's important to acknowledge that therapy can be helpful for many people, even those who may have doubts about its effectiveness. Therapy provides a safe space for you to explore your thoughts, feelings, and behaviors in order to gain insight and develop coping strategies. It's true that therapy requires active participation and willingness, but it's also important to remember that therapists are trained to work with individuals like yourself who may have reservations about therapy. They can tailor their approach to suit your specific needs and help you navigate through the challenges you're facing.

In terms of your self-care, it's concerning to hear that you've given up on taking care of yourself. Not eating for long periods and engaging in sporadic, unhealthy eating patterns can be detrimental to your physical and mental health. It's crucial to prioritize proper nutrition and establish a regular eating routine. Additionally, exercise can be incredibly beneficial for both your physical and mental well-being. Even small steps, such as going for short walks or finding activities that you enjoy, can make a significant difference.

Regarding your skin condition, while it may be painful and uncomfortable, it doesn't justify using it as an excuse for self-harm. Self-harm is a dangerous coping mechanism that can worsen your emotional state and hinder your ability to cope with difficult feelings. It's important to seek healthier ways to manage your emotions, such as talking to someone you trust, engaging in creative outlets, or practicing relaxation techniques.

Your addictive behaviors may also be serving as a way to numb your feelings, but they're not addressing the underlying issues. Consider exploring healthier coping mechanisms that can help you process and express your emotions in a more constructive way. This could include activities like journaling, painting, playing a musical instrument, or even joining a support group where you can connect with others who may be experiencing similar struggles.

Your unhealthy fantasies may provide temporary escape, but they're not helping you engage with reality or find fulfillment in your own life. It's important to ground yourself in the present moment and challenge negative thought patterns that contribute to feeling hopeless or unworthy. Mindfulness exercises, such as deep breathing or body scan meditations, can help bring your focus back to the present and cultivate a sense of self-awareness.

Lastly, it's crucial to address your thoughts of death and the incident with your roommate. These incidents indicate the need for immediate attention and support. Please reach out to a helpline, crisis hotline, or emergency services right away. They can provide you with the necessary support and ensure your safety.

Remember, it's okay to feel lost and uncertain. It takes time and effort to find direction and meaning in life, but it's worth exploring different avenues that resonate with you. Consider reaching out to friends, family, or community organizations for support and guidance. Sometimes, even small steps towards engaging in activities or connecting with others can help you discover hidden passions or opportunities that you may not have considered before.

You don't have to face this alone, and there are people who care about your well-being. Reach out for support, consider therapy as a tool for growth, and take small steps towards self-care. You deserve to live a fulfilling life, even if it feels out of reach right now.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
well i caved i cut myself for the first time today it didn t really hurt but it didn t help either i still feel like shit i can t take it anymore i switched school this year and have yet to make a single friend every day i m on the outside of the group i know that i did something to warrant this problem but no one will tell me what i did am doing i just gave up trying to nudge my way into conversation and just sit there and listen so i don t look like a lonely loser although i guess i look like one anyway anyone have any advice i need social interaction to get out of my depression also looking for new friend won t work a everyone in the grade act like i don t exist so don t suggest that

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I'm really sorry to hear that you're feeling this way, and I want you to know that you're not alone. It takes a lot of courage to reach out and share what you're going through. I can understand how frustrating it must be to feel like you don't have any friends and to be excluded from social groups at school.

Firstly, I want to assure you that what you're experiencing is not your fault. Sometimes, when we're feeling isolated, it's easy to blame ourselves and think that we must have done something to cause it. However, it's important to remember that everyone has their own reasons for behaving the way they do, and it may not always be about something you did.

Instead of focusing on what might have caused this situation, let's focus on finding some solutions. You mentioned that you've tried nudging your way into conversations and sitting there listening, but it hasn't worked so far. Sometimes, initiating conversations can be challenging, especially when everyone else seems to already have their own groups.

One approach you could try is joining a club or extracurricular activity that interests you. This can provide an opportunity to meet people who share similar hobbies or interests, and it can give you a common ground to start conversations. Additionally, being part of a club or team can help boost your self-confidence and sense of belonging.

Another strategy you could consider is reaching out to someone outside of school for social interaction. This could be a family member, relative, or even a neighbor. Sometimes, having a supportive and understanding person to talk to can make a big difference. They may also be able to offer guidance on making friends and navigating social situations based on their own experiences.

In addition to seeking social interaction, it's important to take care of yourself holistically. Engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation can help alleviate some of the symptoms of depression. It could be something as simple as taking a walk in nature, reading a book, or listening to music. Finding healthy coping mechanisms that work for you can be beneficial in managing your emotions.

Lastly, I encourage you to reach out to a trusted adult in your life. It could be a parent, teacher, or school counselor. They may be able to provide you with additional support and guidance. Sometimes, they may not be aware of the difficulties you're facing unless you share it with them.

Remember, healing takes time, and it's okay to ask for help along the way. You deserve to have fulfilling social connections and to feel supported. Don't give up, and keep reaching out for support.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

my other alt account wa deleted so i m posting here today i had a mental breakdown on the basis of what i feel are good thing in my life disappearing inexplicably oftentimes whenever i attempt interaction with aforementioned good thing the last straw wa today over a fairly trivial issue but i broke down because of so many thing that had happened recently in my past that i wa unable to shrug off my life is fairly good and i am very lucky to be living in a household full of opportunity however it feel a though whenever i try to fully indulge in what s provided to me whether it be by my hand or anothers it s normally gone in no time flat about the call i wa in the middle of my breakdown and tried to take the rational course of action calling the hotline because i desperately needed to talk with somebody only to vent my frustration and promptly be hung up on by the person on the other end of the line i tried calling twice more ok case i hung up on then by accident but wa almost immediately disconnected and the last time wasn t able to be connected with anyone fuck what if i were actually about to commit suicide and just wanted someone to talk with only to find out that they didn t care about my problem either it anger me just typing this i m sick of living this way i don t think suicide is the answer but i really just need someone to talk with about my frustration thanks for reading and hopefully your day is better than mine

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're going through a really tough time right now, and I'm glad that you reached out for support. It's understandable that you felt angry and frustrated when you were hung up on by the person you called on the hotline. It can be really disheartening to feel like no one cares about your problem, especially when you're already feeling vulnerable and overwhelmed.

One suggestion I have is to try reaching out to someone in your support system who you trust and feel comfortable talking to. This could be a close friend, family member, or even a teacher or mentor. Sometimes just having someone to listen and validate our feelings can make a big difference. They may not have all the answers, but having a supportive presence can provide comfort and reassurance.

Another option is to consider finding an online community or forum where you can connect with others who may be experiencing similar challenges. These spaces can offer a sense of belonging and understanding, as you're able to share your thoughts and feelings with people who can relate to what you're going through. Just remember to prioritize your safety and well-being by being cautious about sharing personal information online.

In addition to seeking support from others, it might also be helpful to explore some coping strategies that work for you. Engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation, such as hobbies, exercise, or creative outlets, can help distract you from negative thoughts and provide a sense of fulfillment. Developing healthy coping mechanisms, such as deep breathing exercises or journaling, can also be useful tools for managing stress and anxiety.

Lastly, it's important to acknowledge that living in a household with opportunities doesn't necessarily mean that everything else in life will always go smoothly. It's normal to experience setbacks, losses, and disappointments along the way. However, it's important to remind yourself of the strengths and resources you do have, as well as the progress you've made in your life so far. Focusing on these positive aspects can help counterbalance the negative thoughts and feelings you're experiencing.

Remember, you don't have to face this alone. Reach out for support, practice self-care, and be patient with yourself as you navigate through these difficult emotions. You deserve to have someone to talk to and to live a fulfilling life.

i already called in yesterday for work i wa up all night laying here just awake counting down the hour to work wa so exhausted by the time work came around that i called in and even then i couldn t sleep it s now 0 pm and i ve gotten under an hour of sleep in the last 0 hr i m starting to worry a bit this month ha been so hard for me i literally almost walked into traffic on the way to work last week been cry so much i m so alone and it really scare me because i m going through all of this by myself

 It sounds like you've been experiencing a lot of exhaustion and emotional distress lately, particularly in the past month. It's understandable that this has been challenging for you, especially since it seems like you don't have much support.

One thing you can try is establishing a consistent sleep routine. This means going to bed and waking up at the same time every day, even on weekends. Creating a relaxing bedtime routine, such as taking a warm shower or practicing deep breathing exercises, can also help signal to your body that it's time to wind down and prepare for sleep.

In addition to sleep, it's important to prioritize self-care. Find activities that bring you joy and make time for them regularly. Engaging in hobbies, spending time outdoors, or connecting with loved ones (even if it's just through phone calls or video chats) can provide some relief from the stress and loneliness you've been feeling.

Consider reaching out to a trusted friend or family member and sharing what you've been going through. Sometimes just talking about our feelings with someone who cares can provide a sense of relief. They may be able to offer support, advice, or simply lend an empathetic ear.

If you're feeling overwhelmed with emotions, it can be helpful to express them in a way that feels safe for you. Writing in a journal, creating art, or engaging in physical exercise are all outlets that allow you to release and process your emotions.

Lastly, if you haven't already, consider seeking professional help. A mental health therapist can provide guidance, coping strategies, and a non-judgmental space to explore your thoughts and feelings. They can also help you develop healthy ways to manage stress and improve your overall well-being.

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're going through a really tough time right now, and I'm here to offer some guidance and suggestions.

Firstly, it's important to acknowledge the impact that these changes in your living situation and support system can have on your mental health. Depression and thoughts of suicide are serious concerns, and it's crucial to reach out for help when experiencing them. Consider reaching out to a helpline or crisis hotline in your area to speak with someone who can provide immediate support and guidance.

Regarding your strained relationship with your mother and the challenges you're facing, it's understandable that you feel frustrated and unsupported. It seems like there may be a lack of open communication between you and your mother, which can contribute to misunderstandings and further strain the relationship.

In order to address this, it might be helpful to initiate an honest and open conversation with your mother about how you're feeling. Express your concerns about the changes in living arrangements and the impact it will have on your mental health and overall well-being. Clearly communicate your needs and boundaries, while also listening to her perspective and concerns.

Additionally, consider seeking additional support outside of your family. Building a network of friends or even online communities can provide you with emotional support and understanding. Engaging in activities or hobbies that you enjoy, such as playing video games or talking to friends, can also serve as healthy coping mechanisms and provide a sense of freedom and connection.

Regarding your struggle to keep up with your grades and motivation, it's important to remember that self-care is crucial. Take small steps towards taking care of yourself, both physically and mentally. Establishing a routine, setting achievable goals, and breaking tasks down into smaller, manageable parts can help increase motivation and productivity.

Consider reaching out to school resources, such as academic support services or counseling services, for assistance in improving your academic performance. They can provide you with strategies and resources tailored to your specific needs.

Lastly, it's important to prioritize your mental health and seek professional help if possible. A therapist or counselor can provide you with a safe space to express your feelings, gain insight into your experiences, and develop coping strategies. They can also help you navigate your relationship with your mother and improve communication skills.

Remember, you don't have to face these challenges alone. Reach out for support, communicate your needs, and take care of yourself.

[Question]
hi all i m f i ve had very bad anxiety disorder since 0 0 when my uncle passed away the following year i started taking medication and while it help it s not a cure all both my parent passed under different circumstance in october and it s wrecked my emotion i try to do the best i can but sometimes it s just a mess i m out of town right now and i feel so outside of my comfort zone i know i m safe but my stomach is in knot and sorry tmi i haven t left the bathroom much doe anyone have any advice is there anything i can do to calm myself or center myself thank you in advance

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It can be incredibly challenging to deal with anxiety, especially when it has been a long-term struggle like yours. The loss of a loved one, such as your uncle, can trigger intense emotions and make it even more difficult to manage anxiety. It's understandable that the recent passing of both your parents has further impacted your emotional well-being.

When it comes to coping with anxiety, there are several strategies you can try to help calm yourself and find some sense of grounding. One technique is deep breathing exercises. Taking slow, deep breaths can activate the body's relaxation response and help reduce anxiety symptoms. You can try inhaling deeply through your nose for a count of four, holding your breath for a count of four, and then exhaling slowly through your mouth for a count of four. Repeat this process several times until you start to feel more relaxed.

Another helpful strategy is mindfulness meditation. Mindfulness involves focusing your attention on the present moment without judgment. By practicing mindfulness, you can learn to observe your thoughts and feelings without getting overwhelmed by them. There are many guided meditation apps or videos available online that can guide you through mindfulness exercises.

Engaging in physical activity can also be beneficial for managing anxiety. Exercise releases endorphins, which are natural mood boosters. It can help alleviate stress and promote relaxation. Find an activity that you enjoy, whether it's going for a walk, dancing, or doing yoga, and try to incorporate it into your daily routine.

Additionally, it may be helpful to establish a routine and structure in your day. Having a predictable schedule can provide a sense of stability and control, which can be particularly comforting when experiencing anxiety. Plan out your meals, exercise, and self-care activities, as well as any obligations or commitments you have. Having a clear plan can help reduce uncertainty and give you a sense of purpose.

Lastly, don't hesitate to reach out to supportive friends or family members who can offer understanding and empathy. Sometimes just talking about your feelings with someone who cares can provide a great deal of relief. If you're not comfortable discussing your anxiety with someone close to you, consider seeking support from online communities or forums where you can connect with others who may be going through similar experiences.

Remember, managing anxiety is a journey, and it's important to be patient and kind to yourself. It's great that you're already trying your best to cope with the challenges you're facing. These suggestions are meant to provide additional tools that may help you find some relief when you're feeling overwhelmed. Take care of yourself and remember that you're not alone in this.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

i fell pain on my left chest and on my left back when i looking for an answer on google i feel it s a symptom of heart disease my mother also ha this and a far a i know heart disease can be inherited i didn t dare to go to the doctor because in our family there is a saying that say it s better not to know

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's understandable that you're feeling concerned about the pain you've been experiencing in your chest and back. It's important to remember that I am not a doctor, but I can offer some general guidance and suggestions.

Chest and back pain can be caused by various factors, not just heart disease. It could be related to muscle strain, poor posture, or even anxiety. However, since you mentioned that your mother had heart disease and it can be inherited, it would be wise to consider getting checked out by a healthcare professional. They can provide you with an accurate diagnosis and appropriate advice tailored to your specific situation.

While it's natural to have apprehensions about going to the doctor, especially if there's a saying in your family to avoid knowing, it's important to prioritize your health and well-being. Regular check-ups and screenings can help detect potential health issues early on, when they are often more manageable.

If you find it difficult to go directly to the doctor, you could consider alternative steps such as:

1. Self-monitoring: Keep track of any symptoms or changes in your pain levels. Note down when the pain occurs, how long it lasts, and any other relevant details. This information can be helpful when discussing your concerns with a healthcare professional.

2. Lifestyle modifications: Engaging in activities that promote cardiovascular health, such as regular exercise, maintaining a balanced diet, and reducing stress, can contribute positively to your overall well-being. These changes may also alleviate some symptoms you're experiencing.

3. Seek support: Reach out to trusted friends or family members who can provide emotional support during this time. Sometimes talking about your fears and concerns with someone you trust can help alleviate anxiety.

Remember, my intention is to offer guidance, and it's essential to consult a healthcare professional for a proper evaluation and recommendations specific to your situation. They can provide you with the most accurate information based on your medical history and current symptoms.

 It sounds like you're going through a really tough time right now, and I'm here to support you. It's understandable that you're feeling heartbroken and devastated after the situation with your best friend. It can be incredibly difficult when someone we care about so deeply doesn't feel the same way.

Firstly, it's important to remember that these feelings are valid and allowable. It's okay to feel angry at yourself and this world, but it's crucial not to act on those thoughts of ending it all. There are always other options and support available for you.

Regarding your situation with your best friend, it's unfortunate that she accused you of things that aren't true. When emotions run high, misunderstandings can occur, and it's essential to communicate openly about them. If possible, try to have an in-person conversation with her when she is ready. Express how her accusations have affected you and share your perspective on what happened. Honest and respectful communication may help bridge the gap between both of you.

In terms of coping with the heartbreak, it might be helpful to give yourself time and space to grieve. Allow yourself to feel the pain and sadness, as suppressing those feelings can prolong the healing process. Consider finding healthy outlets for your emotions, such as journaling, exercising, or engaging in creative activities. These activities can provide a sense of release and help you process your emotions.

Additionally, reaching out to friends or loved ones who you trust can offer emotional support during this challenging time. They can provide a listening ear and offer advice or different perspectives on your situation. Sometimes talking to someone outside of the situation can provide new insights and help you gain clarity.

Finding purpose and direction in life can take time, especially after experiencing setbacks like failing college classes or not being able to pursue your passion. Exploring your interests and values can be a good starting point. Reflect on what truly matters to you and what brings you joy. Consider setting small, achievable goals that align with your interests and gradually work towards them. Taking small steps towards your goals can help build momentum and regain a sense of direction.

Lastly, it's important to remember that everyone faces challenges in life, and setbacks are a part of our journey. It may be helpful to reframe your thoughts about yourself and your abilities. Instead of thinking "I have no future," try reframing it as "I am facing difficulties right now, but with support and effort, I can work towards a brighter future." Focus on your strengths and past achievements to regain confidence in your ability to overcome obstacles.

Remember, you don't have to face this alone. Reach out to supportive friends, family members, or even helplines available in your area. Caring individuals are there to provide guidance and assistance when you need it most.

i m fine i m fine i m fine until once again i m back in the pit and i m wondering how long do i need to keep doing this for when i stare at my computer screen another fucking 9 day of meaningless clicking so i can earn barely enough money to survive comparing myself with other people my age depresses me i m not so successful and i probably didn t live up to anyones expectation including my own but the more i think about it based on all my trauma and self hatred where i am kinda make sense but the thought of i need to continue living like this idling just living in the same page everyday why i have a vacation booked and then what i come back to the same meaningless routine every time after a vacation im more depressed that my life is how it is do i want to change sure how i don t even have the energy or motivation nor do i have the strength or idea some day i feel like im living in my own paradox or dream that my life isn t even real the past few week i been reliving my trauma and all the shit i went through continuously in my head why i don t even know maybe i m trying to understand myself all i get are mood swing bad attitude and burst of anger maybe i should get on med

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're going through a really tough time right now, and I want you to know that you're not alone in feeling this way. It's completely normal to have ups and downs, especially when dealing with trauma and self-hatred. 

Firstly, it's important to acknowledge that your feelings of being unsuccessful and not living up to expectations, including your own, can be incredibly challenging. Comparing yourself to others can often make these feelings worse, so try to focus on your own journey and accomplishments instead. Remember that success looks different for everyone, and it doesn't always mean having a high-paying job or achieving societal expectations.

Regarding the meaningless routine and lack of motivation, it can be helpful to identify what truly brings you joy and fulfillment in life. Are there any hobbies or activities that you genuinely enjoy? Incorporating those into your daily routine, even if it's just for a short period of time each day, can help break up the monotony and provide a sense of purpose. Additionally, setting small, achievable goals for yourself can give you something to work towards and provide a sense of accomplishment.

The reliving of trauma and the continuous cycle of negative thoughts can be extremely draining. It might be beneficial to explore healthy coping mechanisms such as journaling, talking to a trusted friend or family member, or engaging in relaxation techniques like deep breathing or meditation. These strategies can help redirect your thoughts and manage the mood swings, bad attitude, and bursts of anger that you've been experiencing.

Considering getting on medication is a personal decision, but it could be worth discussing with a healthcare professional who specializes in mental health. They can provide guidance and determine if medication might be beneficial for you. Keep in mind that medication alone may not solve all of your problems, so it's important to consider therapy or counseling as well. A therapist can help you navigate through your trauma, understand yourself better, and develop healthier coping mechanisms.

Lastly, it's important to address the overall lack of energy and strength you're feeling. Taking care of your physical health can have a significant impact on your mental well-being. Make sure you're getting enough sleep, eating nutritious meals, and engaging in regular exercise. These self-care practices can help boost your energy levels and improve your mood.

Remember, change takes time and effort. It's okay to feel frustrated and discouraged, but don't give up on yourself. You deserve happiness and fulfillment, and with the right support and strategies, you can work towards creating a more meaningful and satisfying life.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

i m tired two month clean in hour and yet i am still so hollow i ve driven everyone away i tell myself that it s fine when the suicidal ideation come i tell myself to shut up just one more hour i ll tell myself live another day and maybe you won t fuck it up but i always do maybe i have done some good maybe i m not wholly horrible it s all a lie deep down i know that i am on six attempt to kill myself i m sure this one will be my seventh it s fine

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're going through a really tough time right now, and I want you to know that you don't have to face it alone. It's great that you've been clean for two months and have been able to make progress in your recovery. However, I understand how challenging it can be to still feel empty and hollow despite your efforts.

Driving people away and struggling with suicidal ideation are common experiences for many individuals dealing with mental health issues. It's important to remember that these thoughts and feelings do not define your worth or character. They are often symptoms of underlying pain and suffering.

When suicidal ideation comes up, it can be incredibly difficult to silence those thoughts and find motivation to keep going. One strategy that might help is reaching out to someone you trust, such as a friend or family member, when you're feeling overwhelmed. Sharing your struggles with someone who cares about you can provide support and remind you that you're not alone.

Additionally, it may be helpful to develop coping mechanisms that work for you. Engaging in activities that bring you joy or provide a sense of accomplishment can help combat the emptiness you're feeling. This could include hobbies, exercise, creative outlets, or even simply spending time in nature. Experiment with different activities and see what resonates with you.

It's also important to challenge negative thoughts and beliefs about yourself. Remind yourself of any positive qualities, achievements, or acts of kindness you've engaged in. While it's natural to focus on self-criticism, try to counterbalance those thoughts with self-compassion. Treat yourself with the same kindness and understanding that you would offer to a loved one going through a difficult time.

Lastly, consider seeking professional help if you haven't already. A mental health therapist or counselor can provide guidance tailored to your specific needs and help you develop effective coping strategies. They can also assist in addressing the underlying pain and trauma that may be contributing to your feelings of hopelessness.

Remember, recovery is a journey, and setbacks are a normal part of that journey. It's important to be patient and kind to yourself as you continue to navigate through this challenging time. You're not alone, and there is hope for healing and growth.

[Question]
i have been away from home for week and yesterday i wa scheduled to return my friend had offered to pick me up from the airport for context i don t live in the safest city for woman after i land my friend text me saying they can t pick me up from the airport and i should book a cab and come home i wa at the airport from pm to am because there were no cab available creepy men started following me stating oh no one s here to pick you up i had to go to the police because the men didn t stop following me i had a breakdown in public and i couldn t breathe i finally called a friend who life near by who came to pick me up at around 0 am by then i wa completely wrecked yesterday wa a complete mess and im still feeling anxious and triggered

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you went through a really difficult and distressing experience yesterday. I'm here to offer some guidance and suggestions on how you can cope with the anxiety and triggers you're currently experiencing.

Firstly, it's important to acknowledge that what happened to you was not your fault. You took appropriate steps by seeking help from the police when you felt unsafe, and reaching out to a friend for support. Remember that you acted bravely in a challenging situation.

To address the anxiety and triggers you're feeling, it can be helpful to engage in self-care activities. Self-care involves doing things that promote your physical, mental, and emotional well-being. Consider engaging in activities that bring you joy or relaxation, such as taking a warm bath, listening to calming music, practicing deep breathing exercises, or going for a walk in nature. These activities can help you relax and reduce anxiety.

Additionally, talking about your experience with someone you trust can provide you with emotional support. It could be a close friend, family member, or even a helpline. Sharing your feelings and thoughts with others can help alleviate some of the burden you may be carrying.

When you're ready, it might also be beneficial to create a safety plan for yourself. A safety plan involves identifying steps you can take to protect yourself in similar situations. For example, you could consider having a trusted contact who can accompany you to the airport or arrange for a cab beforehand. Having a plan in place can help you feel more prepared and secure in the future.

Lastly, it's important to remember that healing takes time. It's normal to still feel anxious and triggered after such a traumatic experience. Be patient with yourself and allow yourself to process your emotions at your own pace. If you find that these feelings persist or worsen over time, it may be helpful to seek professional support from a therapist who specializes in trauma. They can provide you with additional guidance and tools to cope with the long-term effects of the traumatic event.

Remember, you are not alone in this journey. There are people who care about you and want to support you. Take care of yourself and reach out for help when you need it.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

 It's really tough to hear that you're feeling this way, but I want you to know that there is hope for getting the help and support you need. It's important to reach out when you're struggling, even if it feels like there aren't many resources available in your small town.

One option you could consider is seeking support online or through phone hotlines. There are several organizations that offer free and confidential counseling services, where trained professionals can listen to you and provide guidance. These hotlines can be a good starting point if you're unsure about how to get help locally.

In addition to professional help, it might also be beneficial for you to build a support network of friends and family members who you trust. Sharing your feelings with someone close to you can make a big difference, as they may be able to offer emotional support and understanding. If you've already written letters to loved ones, it might be worth considering showing them to someone you trust or discussing the content with them.

Engaging in self-care activities can also be helpful in managing depression. While it may feel like you're isolating yourself, finding small ways to take care of yourself can make a difference. This could include things like getting enough sleep, eating nutritious meals, engaging in physical activity, and doing activities that bring you joy or relaxation.

Lastly, I encourage you to reach out to local mental health organizations or community centers. They may have information about local support groups or resources that can assist you. It's worth exploring these options, as they may be able to connect you with people who understand what you're going through and can provide additional guidance on finding help in your area.

[Question]
i don t feel like myself anymore and i don t think i can be fixed not a day go by where i wish i didn t wake up again i don t know what s wrong and i ve been trying so hard to be better i just can t do it anymore i m so sorry

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're going through a really difficult time right now, and I want you to know that you're not alone. It's important to remember that everyone's journey is unique, and what works for one person may not work for another. However, there are some suggestions I can offer that might help you in your process of healing and finding yourself again.

Firstly, it might be helpful to explore the underlying reasons behind your feelings of not being yourself anymore. This could involve reflecting on any major life changes, traumas, or stressful events that have occurred recently. Journaling can be a useful tool to express your thoughts and emotions, as well as gaining clarity on what might be contributing to these feelings.

Additionally, consider seeking support from loved ones or trusted friends. Sharing your feelings with someone who cares about you can provide comfort and understanding. They may also offer different perspectives or coping strategies that have worked for them in similar situations.

Engaging in self-care activities is crucial during this challenging time. Focus on activities that bring you joy and relaxation, whether it's taking a walk in nature, practicing mindfulness or meditation, listening to music, or engaging in hobbies. Taking care of your physical health by getting enough sleep, eating nutritious meals, and exercising regularly can also have a positive impact on your mental well-being.

Exploring therapy options, such as cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) or dialectical behavior therapy (DBT), can be beneficial in understanding and challenging negative thought patterns. These therapies can equip you with effective coping skills to manage distressing thoughts and emotions. Additionally, therapy can provide a safe space for you to process your feelings and gain insights into yourself.

Incorporating positive affirmations into your daily routine can help counteract negative self-talk. Repeating affirmations like "I am worthy," "I deserve happiness," and "I am capable of healing" can gradually shift your mindset towards self-compassion and belief in your own strength.

Lastly, please remember that healing takes time and it's okay to have setbacks along the way. Be patient and kind to yourself throughout this process. You deserve to feel better, and with the right support and strategies, there is hope for you to regain a sense of self and find happiness again.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
im and mo postpartum i don t know if i have ppocd but the intrusive thought are becoming unbearable my baby is healthy and for the most part happy a lot of the time i feel like a shitty mom because i work full time while my boyfriend is at home with the baby and when i get home im too exhausted to clean house or play with my baby i carry so much guilt about other people watching my son on my day off so i can get thing done because i m his mom and i should be able to take care of him and everything else myself tonight he wa losing his sh t bc he wa overtired his screaming made me feel like i wanted to hurt him or myself i would never hurt him but the thought get so loud i can t seem to escape them i wa in a psych hospital last month but it didn t help at all these thought are a constant sometimes i feel like having a baby wa the wrong choice and i ruined my life and the only way to fix my issue is to end it i just feel so alone

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're going through a really tough time right now, and I want to assure you that you're not alone. Many new moms experience intrusive thoughts and feelings of guilt, especially when dealing with the challenges of postpartum life. It's important to remember that having these thoughts doesn't make you a bad person or a bad mother.

Firstly, it's great that you recognize the importance of seeking help and reaching out to a psych hospital last month. While it may not have provided the relief you were hoping for, there are still steps you can take to manage these intrusive thoughts. One effective strategy is cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), which can help you challenge and reframe negative thoughts. CBT techniques can be learned and practiced on your own, or you may consider finding a therapist who specializes in this approach.

Additionally, it's crucial to prioritize self-care and give yourself permission to take breaks. Remember that taking care of yourself is essential for being able to take care of your baby. It's okay to feel exhausted and need time to recharge. Consider reaching out to friends, family, or support groups to see if they can lend a hand with childcare or household tasks. Remember, asking for help doesn't make you any less of a mother - in fact, it shows strength and wisdom in recognizing your own limitations.

When it comes to work, try to communicate openly with your employer about your needs as a new mother. Some workplaces offer flexible arrangements or accommodations that can help alleviate some of the stress. If possible, discuss options such as reduced hours or remote work, even if only temporarily.

Regarding the overwhelming thoughts you had tonight, it's important to reach out for immediate support when they occur. Consider keeping a list of emergency helpline numbers or trusted friends and family members nearby, so you have someone to contact when you're feeling overwhelmed. Speaking with someone who can provide a listening ear and offer reassurance can be incredibly helpful in managing those intense moments.

Lastly, it's common to question whether having a baby was the right choice and feel overwhelmed by the responsibilities of parenthood. It's important to remember that these feelings are normal and often temporary. Many new parents go through similar emotions as they adjust to the major life changes brought by parenthood. If you haven't already, consider joining a support group for new mothers where you can connect with others who are going through or have gone through similar experiences. Sharing your thoughts and concerns with others who understand can provide validation and a sense of belonging.

Remember, you don't have to face this alone. There are resources available to help you navigate these difficult thoughts and emotions. Reach out for support, practice self-care, and consider seeking therapy or counseling to work through these challenges. You deserve to find relief and happiness as you embark on this journey of parenthood.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

also i can t even look nobody in the eye because of it wtf do i do it s ruining the relationship i have with my family and parent it s just pissing me tf off i went to get a haircut today but walked tf out because i wa too anxious and my anxiety wa high so when i walked in i sat all the way in the back so my barber and other people wouldn t see me because of my dumbass anxiety but how else wa i gon na get a cut if he couldn t see me right so like i said i just walked tf out with my head down n cried when i got home

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're experiencing a lot of frustration and anger related to your anxiety, especially when it affects your relationships and daily activities. It must have been difficult for you to go to the hair salon and feel anxious about being seen by others.

One suggestion I have is to consider seeking professional help from a mental health therapist who specializes in anxiety. They can provide you with coping strategies tailored to your specific needs and help you develop techniques to manage your anxiety in different situations. Therapy can also offer a safe space for you to express your feelings and concerns without judgment.

In addition to therapy, there are some self-help strategies that you can try on your own. One approach is called exposure therapy, which involves gradually exposing yourself to situations that trigger anxiety in a controlled and supportive manner. For example, you can start by practicing eye contact with a trusted friend or family member, gradually increasing the duration and intensity over time. This can help desensitize you to the fear of being judged or rejected.

Another technique you might find helpful is deep breathing exercises. When you notice your anxiety rising, take slow, deep breaths in through your nose and out through your mouth. Focus on your breath as it enters and leaves your body, allowing yourself to relax with each exhale. Deep breathing can help activate your body's relaxation response and reduce anxiety symptoms.

Additionally, engaging in regular physical exercise can be beneficial for managing anxiety. Exercise releases endorphins, which are natural mood boosters, and helps reduce stress levels. Find an activity that you enjoy, whether it's walking, dancing, or playing a sport, and aim for at least 30 minutes of moderate-intensity exercise most days of the week.

Lastly, consider reaching out to a support network, such as friends or family members, who can provide emotional support and understanding. Sometimes just talking about your anxiety with someone who cares can alleviate some of the burden you're carrying.

Remember, managing anxiety takes time and effort, but with the right support and strategies, it is possible to improve your relationships, regain confidence, and live a fulfilling life.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

If you find it difficult to face therapy this week, it might be helpful to communicate this to your therapist beforehand if possible. They can provide you with alternative options or help you explore other coping strategies in the meantime. In addition to therapy, there are other steps you can take to support your mental health. Have you considered incorporating self-care activities into your daily routine? Engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation, such as exercise, hobbies, or spending time in nature, can help improve your mood and overall well-being.

Building a strong support system is also crucial. Reach out to trusted friends or family members who can offer emotional support. Exploring healthy coping mechanisms can also be beneficial. This could involve practicing deep breathing exercises, mindfulness techniques, or meditation. These practices can help you develop better control over your thoughts and emotions and reduce stress levels.

Lastly, please remember that healing takes time and setbacks are a normal part of the process. It's important to be patient and kind to yourself as you navigate this journey. [Question]
dutifully working a job that doesn t care about my humanity training people to replace me dutifully caring for a pet that make my mental health worse training them a i stress cry dutifully filling out tax for my dead parent emailing lawyer because my sibling won t fulfill their legal obligation dutifully attending counseling with my spouse actively listening to being told my want and need are wrong dutifully laying in bed quietly so a not do disturb anyone else staring at the ceiling through insomnia and intrusive thought understanding that i don t exist i am just a tool for everyone else this is my duty

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you are feeling overwhelmed and undervalued in various aspects of your life. It's important to remember that your feelings and needs matter, and you deserve to be treated with kindness and respect. Here are some suggestions and guidance for each of the situations you mentioned:

1. Job: If you feel your humanity is not valued at work, it can be helpful to seek out opportunities where your unique qualities and contributions are appreciated. Consider exploring other job options or talking to your supervisor about how you can contribute in a way that aligns with your values.

2. Pet: Caring for a pet can bring joy, but if it's impacting your mental health negatively, it's important to prioritize your well-being. Consider seeking support from friends, family, or local pet organizations to help with the caregiving responsibilities.

3. Taxes: Dealing with taxes can be overwhelming, especially when grieving the loss of a parent. Reach out to professionals who specialize in tax preparation or seek guidance from reliable online resources. They can provide assistance and ensure everything is handled correctly.

4. Legal obligations: When siblings or family members refuse to fulfill their legal obligations, it can create additional stress. Consider consulting with a lawyer to understand your options and protect your rights.

5. Counseling: Attending counseling with your spouse can be beneficial for improving your relationship. However, if you consistently feel your wants and needs are being invalidated, open and honest communication is essential. Express your concerns calmly and assertively, emphasizing that understanding and validating each other's perspectives is crucial for growth.

6. Sleep: Dealing with insomnia and intrusive thoughts can be challenging. Establishing a relaxing bedtime routine and creating a comfortable sleep environment might help improve your sleep quality. Try incorporating relaxation techniques such as deep breathing exercises or meditation before bed. If these strategies don't work, consider consulting a healthcare professional for further guidance.

7. Existential crisis: Feeling like you're just a tool for everyone else can be disheartening. Take some time to reflect on your own values, interests, and aspirations. Engage in activities that bring you joy and fulfillment, even if they seem selfish at first. It's important to prioritize self-care and reconnect with your own identity.

Remember, you don't have to go through this alone. Seek support from trusted friends, family members, or even online communities where you can share your experiences and receive empathy. Taking care of your mental health is crucial, so consider reaching out to a mental health professional who can provide personalized guidance and support tailored to your specific needs.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
sorry if this is the wrong subreddit for a long time in my life all i wanted wa to have someone to be there for me a person that could love me back a much i love them back but now that i have it i don t know if it s what i wanted in my past i had suicidal friend that influenced a huge part of my life i begin to realize how stupid living wa and started to question why we live i m losing all my energy slowly and slowly i find myself losing all motivation and having no goal or dream anymore this reddit is my last ditch effort on seeking help from other people i ve already started to distance from everyone around me i know that i can t be the only one that s been or going through this how were you guy able to keep your energy and have a positive outlook on life

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you've been through a lot and are currently going through a difficult time. It's understandable that you're feeling lost and unsure about what you truly want in life, especially when you have had a past influenced by suicidal thoughts and question the purpose of living.

Firstly, it's important to acknowledge that seeking help is a positive step and shows strength. Many people go through similar experiences and struggle with motivation and a sense of purpose. While I can't speak for everyone, I can share some suggestions that may help you regain your energy and find a more positive outlook on life.

1. Self-reflection: Take some time to reflect on your values, interests, and passions. What activities or hobbies used to bring you joy? Engaging in activities aligned with your values can help rekindle a sense of meaning and motivation.

2. Small goals: Start setting small, achievable goals for yourself. These goals don't have to be grand or overwhelming. They can be as simple as going for a walk every day, trying out a new recipe, or completing a small task you've been putting off. Celebrate each accomplishment, no matter how small.

3. Social support: Even though you mentioned distancing yourself from others, having a support system is crucial. Reach out to trusted friends or family members who can provide emotional support. Consider joining support groups or online communities where you can connect with people who may be going through similar challenges.

4. Self-care: Prioritize self-care activities that help you relax and recharge. This could include getting enough sleep, eating nutritious meals, exercising regularly, practicing mindfulness or meditation, or engaging in activities that bring you pleasure.

5. Professional help: While I'm not an expert, seeking professional help such as therapy or counseling can provide valuable guidance and support tailored to your specific needs. A mental health professional can help you explore your feelings, develop coping strategies, and work towards finding meaning and motivation in life.

Remember, it's okay to not have all the answers right now. Life is a journey, and sometimes it takes time to discover what truly brings us fulfillment. Be patient with yourself and keep seeking support from those around you. You are not alone in this, and there are people who care about your well-being.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i am year old and i finallly came to the conclusion that i need help with anxiety i signed up for therapy and will have my first session in a couple of day prior to the therapy session i met with a prescriber to discus medication they recomended starting me off on zoloft or lexapro in general i tend to think of medication a a last resort not just for thing like this but in all aspect for example i rarely used medinces perscribed to me for pain after surgery and would only use them if absolutely necesarry i don t even like taking ibuprofen for a headache unless it is unbearable given that i am trying to figure out whether or going on anxiety medication is necessary for me or not i am worried about going on something for the rest of my life and am a little concerned about the side effect on the other hand i have been reading some post on here about how much med helped people i am hoping to hear from some people that have been on any of these medication and what their experience were also if anyone ha any thought on whether or not someone that is new to this whole anexiety improvement journey should jump into med or just try therapy first and see how that go i always kind of ignored my anxiety and told myself that since i have been able to graduate from college with a good degree hold down a great job for several year and maintain good relationship that my anxiety must not be that bad but a time go by i am starting to feel like it is getting worse and is negatively impacting my happiness and is leading my to lean on stimulant and alcohol too much which doesn t seem like a long term healthy way of handling this i have also had a couple of concussion in the last few year so i am not sure how much that play into what i am going through i would really appreciate it if some people could speak to their experience or have any encouragement or advice for someone just starting out in therapy and potentially medication please reach out if i can add additional context to my situation to help clarity where i am at also i wa reading some other post on this sub about people being tired all of the time i have spent year trying to figure out medically why to no avail i am starting to wondering if my axiety is causing it can anyone speak to any experience or epiphany they have had with this thanks garrison

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's great that you've recognized the need for help with your anxiety and taken steps to seek therapy. It's understandable that you may have concerns about medication, especially considering you prefer to use it as a last resort. Many people share similar thoughts about medication, especially when it comes to long-term use and potential side effects.

To gather more information, it can be helpful to hear from others who have experience with anxiety medication. They can provide insights into their personal experiences and help you understand what to expect. While everyone's experience is unique, hearing different perspectives might give you a better idea of whether medication could be beneficial for you.

In terms of deciding whether to start medication or try therapy first, there isn't a one-size-fits-all answer. Therapy can be an excellent starting point to explore your anxiety further, develop coping strategies, and gain insights into its impact on your life. Some individuals find that therapy alone is sufficient in managing their anxiety, while others benefit from a combination of therapy and medication. It ultimately depends on your specific needs and preferences.

Considering your history of ignoring your anxiety and telling yourself it must not be that bad, it's important to recognize that anxiety can manifest differently for each person. Just because you've achieved academic and professional success and maintained relationships doesn't mean your anxiety isn't significant or impacting your happiness. Anxiety can sometimes be overlooked or underestimated, so acknowledging its presence and seeking support is commendable.

Regarding your concussions, it's possible that they may contribute to what you're experiencing. Concussions can have lasting effects on cognitive function, emotional well-being, and overall quality of life. It may be worth discussing this with your therapist or prescriber, as they can provide guidance on how to address any concussion-related symptoms and determine if they're contributing to your current situation.

Feeling tired all the time can indeed be related to anxiety. Heightened anxiety can disrupt sleep patterns and leave you feeling drained. If you haven't already, consider discussing your fatigue with your therapist or prescriber. They can help identify any underlying factors contributing to your tiredness and develop strategies to address them.

Remember, this journey is unique to you, and there's no right or wrong way to approach it. Starting therapy and exploring different coping mechanisms is a great first step. From there, you and your therapist can assess whether medication might be beneficial for managing your anxiety. It's important to keep an open mind and remember that medication doesn't have to be a lifetime commitment. Start by discussing your concerns and goals with your therapist, and together you can make an informed decision about the best course of action for you.

Feel free to add any additional context that may help clarify your situation. It's valuable to share as much information as possible so that those providing guidance can offer personalized advice. Remember, you're taking a positive step towards addressing your anxiety, and support is available to help you navigate this journey.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

lol not literally but when i m out with a group of people for example i always feel so weird like i don t belong or that i m so abstract from everyone but in reality i m accepted by everybody amp it rlly suck feeling this way anyone else go through this

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I can understand how you might feel when you're out with a group of people and you experience those uncomfortable feelings of not belonging or being detached from everyone else. It's important to remember that what you're feeling is not uncommon, and many people go through similar experiences.

One suggestion I have is to try practicing self-compassion. Remind yourself that it's okay to have these thoughts and emotions, and they don't define your worth as a person. Treat yourself with kindness and understanding, just as you would treat a close friend who is going through a tough time.

Another helpful strategy could be to challenge any negative thoughts or beliefs you may have about yourself in these situations. Often, our own self-perception can be distorted, and we may see ourselves in a more negative light than others do. Try to identify any irrational thoughts or assumptions you might be making about yourself, and replace them with more realistic and positive ones.

Additionally, it might be beneficial to engage in activities or hobbies that help you feel more connected to others. Find common interests or join groups where you can meet like-minded individuals who share similar passions. This can provide opportunities for you to connect on a deeper level and build meaningful relationships.

Lastly, consider seeking support from a trusted friend or family member. Talking about your feelings with someone you trust can provide validation and reassurance. They may also offer different perspectives or suggestions for coping strategies that have worked for them.

Remember, you are not alone in feeling this way, and there are steps you can take to manage these uncomfortable emotions. You deserve to feel accepted and connected, and with time and effort, you can develop more self-confidence and a stronger sense of belonging.

i come from a pretty african evangelical household where mental health wasn t talked about or addressed growing up in the last few year i ve noticed intense wave of sadness and internal pain turn from short stint of time to practically everyday now there will be time period of elation but for the most part my disposition ha remained sad on an almost daily basis i feel anger irritability deep sadness about the way thing haven t worked out for me in the past or currently or intense rejection from others who may not intend their action to be rejection for example the housemate i live with are a married couple who i wa in their wedding so we re all friend when i first moved in they would always have dinner with me asking me what i wanted to eat for dinner but that ha tapered off and tonight i walked in from work late and saw they had dinner together and were enjoying tv it broke me and i went to my room feeling intense inner pain this stuff is so new to me i have no clue how to continue through life because nobody know i struggle with this i don t even know where to begin to share with others or begin to understand what help i need any advice would be much appreciated

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you've been experiencing a wave of sadness and internal pain that has become more frequent over time. It's understandable that this can be overwhelming and confusing, especially since mental health wasn't addressed or talked about in your household growing up.

One suggestion I have is to consider seeking support from someone you trust, such as a close friend or family member. Sharing your struggles with them might help you feel less alone and provide an opportunity for understanding and empathy. If you're comfortable, you could try opening up to your housemates and expressing how their actions make you feel. Communication is important in any relationship, and it's possible that they may not realize the impact their behavior has on you.

Additionally, it might be helpful to explore different coping mechanisms that work for you. Engaging in activities that bring you joy or relaxation, such as hobbies, exercise, or spending time in nature, can help improve your mood and reduce stress. Developing a self-care routine can also be beneficial, as it allows you to prioritize your own well-being and make time for activities that recharge you emotionally.

Finding a healthy outlet for your emotions is crucial. Journaling can be a powerful tool for processing your thoughts and feelings. Writing down your experiences, thoughts, and emotions can provide clarity and release any built-up tension. Additionally, you could consider joining support groups or online communities where you can connect with others who may have similar experiences. Sometimes sharing with people who understand firsthand can be incredibly validating and comforting.

Lastly, it's important to remember that reaching out for professional help, such as therapy, can be incredibly valuable. Therapists are trained to provide guidance and support tailored to your specific needs. They can help you gain insight into your emotions, develop coping strategies, and work towards understanding what kind of help would be most beneficial for you.

Remember, it takes time and patience to navigate through these challenges. Be kind to yourself throughout this process and know that you deserve support and understanding.
